Fan gets loud under heavy work but not point where it would be annoying. Sound quality is good but bass is minimal. Since asked about photo editing and video editing ignore advice get a gaming laptop. Those are NOT designed for photo editing. You a laptop decent thermals for sure but mostly a high-resolution color-accurate display that supports 100% Adobe SRGB and DP3 color space. Most gaming laptops are 1080p or 1440p at best and are not designed for color accuracy at all. They are designed for very fast refresh rates which are useless for photo and video editing. Apple MacBook Pro line HP Z line HP Spectre x360 OLED screen and higher-end Dell XPS are all examples of laptops a suitable screen for what are trying do. MacBook Pro 13 is probably only one available for under 1400 although Spectre x360 OLED be found under 1400 on sale. MacBook Pro also has T2 chip which dramatically accelerates video encoding and takes load off MacBook’s CPU. One alternative suggestion? iPad Pro 12.9 and Apple Magic Keyboard and Pencil. This is a very good photo editing machine that run Photoshop Procreate Adobe Fresco iMovie and others. iPad has an incredible high resolution bright LCD which suppports DP3 color gamut. Apple pencil is hands down best drawing and stylus input available. And Magic Keyboard makes iPad a real candidate for laptop replacement.

Before Magic Keyboard I would have said “absolutely no way.” But Magic Keyboard is transformative. I’m using one now on 2018 iPad Pro write this post. Incredible. Even so I’m going say “maybe.” You didn’t list what your course of study is so that have an impact on answer your question. But generally ’ll be sure that 1. There are no applications that are either not available on iPad or very limited on iPad. For example yes Excel is available on iPad but it is not capable of opening more complex spreadsheets every iPadOS version gets closer but it won’t match desktop versions for years ever . Photoshop on iPad is also not as capable as desktop version. Etc. etc. 2. You live iPad multitasking which is really just 2-app-tasking some app switching. This is also improving but iPad just doesn’t do more than a couple of tasks at once very well at all. You could get frustrated are trying participate in a Zoom lecture take notes and do research at same time. 3. You don’t an external monitor. Many college students get a cheap external LCD monitor for their apartment or dorm come home and write papers and do research on while using a large screen. Almost any LCD tv also act as an external monitor and do double duty that way. IPad only mirror its screen not extend its screen so ’ll just end up looking at a copy of what’s on your iPad screen. Again this could change future iPadOS releases but now it is an issue. Now as Good 1. Magic keyboard and trackpad is a game changer. might actually be worth price 2. With Apple Pencil iPad becomes an excellent maybe best digital note taker 3. Pull iPad off keyboard and have an excellent tablet for reading eBooks watching videos playing games etc. 4. iPadOS files app now gives iPad a legitimate file manager which works well local files and cloud storage 5. Apple has done an excellent job of supporting iPads over time so should expect a new 2020 iPad get 5 years of OS updates 6. LIDAR scanner in new iPad Pros could be put some really cool uses in future 7. IPad be a delight carry around class and back given its size and weight 8. IPad has plenty of CPU power so won’t be lacking in that area. is actually faster than MacBook Air. 9. IPad applications are becoming more and more capable all time and so in future should expect more and more equivalency desktop versions I could afford an iPad Pro 12.9 Apple Pencil and Magic Keyboard or MacBook Air 16/512 that would be a tough choice. Worst case get iPad setup and see it works. it doesn’t get yourself a cheap PC laptop for 500 later and use it for whatever iPad won’t do.

I think Surface Pro 7 is an excellent choice. There are decent sales and Costco usually offers SP7 keyboard and pen for 1000. Put an Urban Armor Gear case on that thing and ’ll have a backpack-friendly tough little tablet and laptop. biggest challenge may be kickstand design takes up a lot of table space and may not work well on small writing desk in lecture halls. For taking notes though Surface Pro is great. other alternative is 2-in-1 style laptop like HP Envy or HP Spectre x360. 2-in-1s are better laptops and worse tablets than Surface. I find for note taking pen thickness of 2-in-1s is less than ideal and I personally don’t like weight of them as a tablet nor do I like feeling keyboard and trackpad on bottom when screen is folded over. On Surface just pull off type cover and ’ll have a more normal tablet. Cool trick on surface pull off type cover and reattach backwards so that it becomes back of surface. I saw that in a video and though “why don’t they that more obvious?” Genius. You likely get a bit more hardware for your money get something like HP Envy but really a tablet that replace your laptop one that be made durable for kicking around in a backpack and is great for note-taking then SP7 is an excellent choice.

Pixelbook Go runs on ChromeOs - a dekstop/mobile os where 't run your normal apps like on windows or macos. You install android apps on it and lately it got support for running linux apps not sure what distro is based on but whole process is overhwelming and i wouldn't consider this Chromebook for your work at all. Even as a Chromebook is very expensive point of chromebooks is be as cheap as possible and have access a browser now android apps but not cost 600 . At that pricepoint have consider laptops true desktop OSes. I'm a senior Cs student and a software dev wanna be. I'm familiar web dev but said that 're just starting out as a web dev. Maybe know by now that not just software development but specifically web development is a very broad aspect has a lot of different technologies etc. Are trying become a backend dev? A front-ent? Backend and DevOps engineer? A full stack dev a.k.a software engineer usually frontend backend devops all together ? For all of these positions don't a laptop a good gpu or dedicated gpu at all well depending on project 're working on over 90% of time won't a good gpu. Unfortunately cannot install any IDEs frameworks etc directly on chromeos have do that through that linux-support alternative which isn't that good on this regard and also not every dev-related app or whatever has linux support. I just wanted first clarify that there is no such thing as mAcOs iS sO mUcH bEtTer fOr sOftWaRe dEvElOpmEnT . That's not true at all. Depending on what do as a software dev windows and gnlinux have advantages over macOs because of support. And vice versa macOs over 2 f.e for ios app development. You dual boot windows or gnlinux macos but there is hardware compatibility issues and won't get full macOs app support also nvidia gpu driver support is officialy non existent since 2014 or something there are fan made driver support but that's not an issue since won't a dedicated gpu for work at all as i mentioned earlier. Also don't trust people who say macOs' terminal is soo much better bcz macos is unix based and run commands on it and bla bla bla guess what? You have equivalent terminal commands on window's cmd/powershell. Now that it has linux support write same terminal commands as would in a gnlinux distro. Also those macOs commands that most talk about those people usually just navigate through directories and brag about terminal lol . I know it sound overhwelming but at least now have necessery info about what 'll really for your work. So mentioned 2000Cad. For that price get a laptop excellent build quality very good screen quality great batterylife and cpu performance for most part while having a small body overall. Since weight is important for a laptop a screen under 15.6 diagonally might be ideal. a 13.3-14 screen i wouldn't recommend standard 16 9 ratio since for smaller screens 16 9 seems very short. More vertical space is highly appreciated for work 're doing but we get narrower display. F.E we compare a 13.3 16 9 screen and a 13.3 16 10 screen macbook pro 13's or xps 13 9300's that 16 10 screen is bigger though diagonally they're same in area that 16 10 is a bit bigger but it is narrower horizontaly but taller vertically. There are also 3 2 screens which are taller but more narrow f.e Surface Laptop 3 either 13 which is 13.5 diagonally or 15 Surface Book 3 13/15 Huawei Matebook X Pro a new Acer 13 that just got released etc although there aren't a lot of 3 2 screen laptops on market. On cpus at least a quadcore cpu is necessery. Intel's 10 gen either comet lake or ice lake are most common for that 2000cad price. An Ice Lake i5 is very similar in performance an Ice Lake i7 search on google for these similarities so getting an i7 is not necessary. On other hand a comet lake i5 i5 10210U is a quadcore cpu and an i7 10710U like on my Prestige 15 in a 6 core/12 thread cpu which works around 80-100% better than that i5 depending on how laptop manufacturers configure those cpus. Just because there is a U at end of cpu instead of an H doesn't mean that U series cpu is weaker than H series. Msi configured that 10710u perform its limits so its performance is same as an i7 9750H that would find in a Macbook Pro 16 i confirm this . Unfortunately that i7 10710u doesn't perform same on smaller laptops like it does in my Prestige 15 because of cooling f.E in a last gen Dell Xps 13 9380 and Lenovo X1 Carbon 7th gen i guess 10710u performs around 20% worse. Anyway there are new Amd ryzen 4th gen mobile cpus that perform better than all intel cpus for a lower price. Also they perform better while pulling less wattage or same depending on cpu . I've seen ASUS mentioned a lot here. For my two cents while it's not most obnoxious model on their catalog I have GA502 and it's kind of a hot potato. Mothership might be better but after dealing their horrible 'Armoury Crate' software awful cooling system in GA502 and genuinely dismissive and decidedly unhelpful support system company has I wouldn't go ASUS. Their motherboards for desktops are pretty great and their laptops used be incredible but it just doesn't feel that way anymore. Alienware M15 R3 just launched and it has a neat vapor chamber cooling system that supposedly improves thermals by a significant margin. Reviews aren't out yet though so we'll see that hold true. Area 51M is just a beast and absolutely fits 'Onnoxious' criteria though I'm not sure about thermals which should be among most important things look for when select a PC. Outside of Dell's swanky Alienware series MSI has some neat designs and Razer Blade has some slightly subdued aesthetic language but looks and feels just as gamer-y as would hope. Happy searching!

Intel used be better but was in lead for so long they got lazy and got leapped frogged by AMD who was almost bankrupt and needed innovate its way out of it. They took a gamble on their Ryzen chips in 2016 and 7nm process node last year and they have been killing Intel across desktop workstation server and now finally laptops their Ryzen 4000 series. reason is they are using TSMC'S 7nm process and chiplets design for it's CPU basically they glue chips together higher skus. They are all same just glued cores. Intel is still on 14nm because they design their own chips and saw no push innovation as they were ahead so much. So now they have been at 14nm since 2014. And they still 't just shrink their node because of their monolithic design their chips and issues trying shrink down 10nm. Basically Intel be behind till at least 2023 and by then AMD be on 5nm. Long story short AMD is better option. Cheaper more performance more cores better battery more secure. intel is popular and they are a massive company so it's gonna take time for people really see how ahead AMD is. For video editors majority use AMD now because of high core count CPUs they offer for fairly cheap 3900x is a 12 core CPU for 389 They offer a 64 core monster afford a 4000 chip. Either way Intel is still bigger but it really is a David and Goliath story.

This applies iPadOS apps that might using which may not be available on Windows 10. 2. Decide a tablet that replace your laptop Surface Pro or a laptop that replace your tablet 2-in-1 . 2-in-1s are great laptops that act as a tablet in a pinch but they are 90% Laptop. taking notes on one vs. iPad be a disappointment. Windows 10 is a very good desktop and laptop OS although may be surprised how much time spend tweaking it vs. what are used on Mac that do just about anything . size and thickness them cumbersome tablets and anything above 13 inches is pretty impossible use as a tablet. Surface is much more akin a tablet that replace a laptop. Windows 10 is not a great tablet OS so may miss your iPad. However Surface hardware is very nice as a tablet and generally use a surface like a tablet in a way 't easily use a 2-in-1. surface screen is smaller than virtually all 2-in-1s and using a Surface on a lap is an exercise in futility. I would assume laptops gpus tend produce more heat and more heat leads higher rates of failure. and thats what I think is probably cause of all those Razer laptops defects. Louis Rossmann once invited a repair guy specializing in Razer repairs explain internal designs. IRC cooling system was generally not very good. combined a thin chassis leads a shorter life span I think those that are super thick and heavy such as those Clevo laptops probably last longer comparatively. this is just my guess

As any product . More parts means more failure points. I'm not surprised about toughbook. They are over engineered focus on being durable. So it would be fair assume they would outlive most other models. But I'd assume as a whole integrated systems are more prone failure for simple fact that most of low end market and budget models are made as cheap as possible. I'd think it be more interesting compair pricepoint failure rate. On a purely anecdotal note I've bought and owned many laptops over years many brands Dell budget tier are ones I've had most trouble . So much so I've tended avoid them for last 8 or so years so no idea how they are now. Also my longest lasting laptop was a core 2 based Sony Vaio I think person that inherited it still used it up until last year. So almost 11 years .

Only hardware makers know actual failure rates and then they would an identical model where primary difference is GPU/no-GPU. But anecdotally according ever-accurate Internet chat rooms laptops dedicated graphics cards DO fail quite a bit more. is very plausible for 3 related reasons 1. More heat overall as another heat-generating component is squashed into a small area 2. Users who buy these laptops tend use them for more intensive sustained tasks leading .... more heat 3. GPU makers overestimated their components abilities deal heat NVIDIA was famous for a run of GPUs failing Thin laptops and hot components are in conflict. Having ample airflow and big fans is not what most laptop buyers - they thin and quiet. Microsoft Surface Book is rare exception CPU in tablet lid and GPU in base which enabled both components heat up independently and indeed it punches above its weight on sustained tasks vs most ultrabook-type devices as it isolate each heat producing element in a different part of device. I would guess big clunky gaming laptops would do better since they are designed handle heat HOWEVER gaming laptops fall into trap 2 above and run heat-producing games for long periods of time under pretty heavy loads. Even more of a challenge is that CPU and GPU in most laptops are quite close together often sharing same heat pipe meaning heat from one actually be quickly passed other.
I’m curious hear what people say. lurk

I dont think its a video card thing more than product family. gaming lines are always better build quality than budget or mainstream lines. Normally a laptop a separate GPU is better because it has better battery motherboard power supply case hinges monitor panels and those are biggest points of failure. IE HP Omen fail less than Envy which fail less than a Pavillion which fail less than HP no name family fairest comparison I is budget garbage Acer Aspire 5 family. You get same specs a non-gaming/light gaming gpu like MX250 or same exact specs without gpu for 75-100 less. I've gotten 3 gpus. all 3 got fried mother boards in under 2 years. Meanwhile only a quarter of non-gpu aspires have had major issues usually failed fan screen or power adaptor only gpu version have had complete mobo power failures. but thats aspire 200- 600 slapdash disposable laptops. Since said wanted get hyped up I'll tell about my experiences my Dell XPS 13! To put it simply it's incredible don't have any affiliation Dell in any way and have pretty neutral opinions about company were wondering - build quality is quite impressive as I was coming from a MacBook Air Early 2015 model and was expecting really poor build quality in comparison but XPS holds up really nicely. - A more subtle feature of this laptop that people don't talk about or hype up enough is carbon fiber palm rest. 's soft touch and honestly makes my typing experience so much more enjoyable in general. 's nice that Dell put in this much thought when they could have followed trend that every other laptop was setting and just left us a regular metal palm rest and no one would have ever complained. - Seeing as 're getting XPS 15 and I have 13 I imagine power is going be absolutely amazing on your device. For me and my purposes my XPS has shown be a power-house. performs all tasks I ask it quickly and I've been able do light gaming on it though I have an integrated graphics chip. - thermals are pretty good on my machine. only ever gets hot when I play some games on it Sims 4 and COD mainly which is expected since I don't have a discrete graphics chip. Even when it does get hot though it does so towards back of machine so it shouldn't ever be uncomfortable. People are right when they say it gets really hot but for average person someone who doesn't game a whole lot or do much photo/video editing or CAD work it shouldn't get those points on a regular basis. Dell does this get maximum performance because by letting machine hit a high temperature it's allowing for peak performance happen for a longer time and then laptop thermal throttle and come down. - Now part that seem most hyped about -- screen! I have 4K version as well I have a 2-in-1 so configuration I got forced me get 4K display and it's so good! I really enjoy watching YouTube videos and shows or movies on Netflix this. 's such a game-changer because everything and I mean everything looks absolutely gorgeous on it. I started appreciate typing on Google Docs and just browsing websites more because colors are so vivid and I don't know how describe display other than crisp. Everything just packs a little punch font on this post looks nice. I hope this helped hype up and feel free ask me any questions!

AMD 4000 processors are absolutely legit They offer more cores for less money and less power consumption. only issue is that since Intel is so big and established they are able be in alot different laptops AMD is slowly starting be added better and better models but still limited in options. I recommend Ryzen 4000 series over pretty much all Intel chips because it literally is a plus at almost every front go ryzen. Intel i3 starts at 2 cores Ryzen 3 starts at 4 cores Intel i5 is typically 4 cores Ryzen 5 is now 6 cores. Intel i7 is typically 4 cores for most and 8 cores at crazy high end Ryzen 7 has 8 cores at very low power consumption. Linus did a test where a Ryzen 9 4900H was more powerful than massive laptops 8 core Intel chips using 90W of power while 8 core Ryzen was using about 35W. I'll link it here. So in terms of CPU Ryzen 4000 absolutely smokes almost entire Intel lineup but since it's new there are limited laptop options still.

You get a hundred opinions on this question and they are all right. All wrong too. Mac-vs-PC question has been raging for almost 4 decades. Here is what advice I usually give. Go for Windows 10 Gaming especially latest AAA games Touch screen 2-in-1 and/or active stylus support You hardware that isn’t available on MacBook without using a dongle USB-A HDMI SD card slot Ethernet port etc or a really large or really small screen. most powerful hardware specs for least amount of money You use an application which is unavailable on MacOS Your budget is less than 1000 Get a MacOS laptop Impeccable hardware design and quality and when Apple does screw up they are more likely launch a repair campaign or warranty extension than PC manufacturers Top notch support online and via local Apple stores Way better included software like iPhoto iMovie Notes GarageBand etc. High quality screens well suited for photo video editing MacBook Pros support DP3 color gamut for example Benfits of MacOS ecosystem Especially use an iPhone including iMessage Keychain App Store Handoff iCloud Apple Pay Apple TV etc. You have more than 1000 budget Macs hold their value WAY better than PCs so some of higher upfront cost is recovered years later on resale So which is best for ? Hard say without knowing more. Generally ’ll find that comparing like-for-like specs pay a bit more for a Macintosh but not as much as might think and get a LOT of great free benefits like software above and better resale. I think most typical users find a Mac be more satisfying choice especially they use an iPhone. For gamers or people on a tight budget Windows 10 is clear winner. Flame suit on -

Part 2 on what system specs ? Again varies a lot by use case. For most people 8/256 is bare minimum in 2020. That should be sufficient for typical tasks on both MacOS and Windows10. I generally advise people get more RAM and then more storage because You always add external storage but ’t add external RAM Applications and OSs released in future require more RAM than today so RAM helps longevity RAM in most laptops and all MacBooks is not upgradeable so get what get forever cloud makes local storage less critical do get tight on space However buying MORE RAM than provide exactly zero speed improvements. So overbuying is just a waste of money. 8GB is sufficient for most users in 2020 but 16 GB provides more future proofing. like keeping 20 Chrome tabs open your mail app music player video conferencing then 16gb is probably a good choice now. IF are working massive photo files that have lots of layers or very complex video editing ’ll know this is then might more than 16GB. Again more than 16gb probably know that very well. x200B Based on what ’ve said I think should look at 1 2020 MacBook Pro 10th Gen i5 / 16/ 512. 1799 2 2020 MacBook Pro 8th gen i5 /16 /512 1599 3 2020 MacBook Air 10th gen i5 16/256 1299 4 2020 MacBook Air 10th gen i5 8/256 1099

You dGPU for those applications. No MBA have them. At a similar price point try lower end gaming laptops like new ASUS TUF A15. dGPU help a lot in these applications.

Will those apps run on base i3? Yes. For sure. Will those apps run performance acceptable ? Maybe. In USA upgrading from i3 i5 is only 100 and doubles number of available cores which provide a HUGE jump in short-term multicore performance. That is likely a no-brainer upgrade for most people. Why do I say short term? Because any lengthy processor-intensive task which heat-loads CPU run right into MacBook Air’s weak thermal headroom and begin downshift CPU frequency. At some point a sustained heavy load 4 core i5 and 2-core i3 end up performing about same as limitation becomes how much heat MacBook Air dissipate spoiler alert not much . MacBook Air is really designed for ‘typical’ workloads which just tax CPU for small bursts. MBA is more than capable of handling this type of load. Sustained tasks like rendering on other hand are not well suited MBA as it cannot keep its CPU cool enough over longer periods of time. One of my most ongoing head-scratching questions is why Apple does not connect CPU cooling fan a heat pipe on 2018-2020 MacBook Airs. Crazy. prior MacBook Air and all of MacBook Pros have heat pipes as do virtually all mainstream PC laptops. Is Base 2020 MBA better than 2019 MBP? No. MBA is worse in all but 2 areas. 2019 MacBook Pro is better 4 core 8th gen 25watt CPU vs. 2 core 10th gen 9 watt CPU Higher resolution screen DP3 color space suppport vs. not 100 Nits brighter screen backlight Much better thermal headroom Better speakers 2020 MacBook Air better .25 pound lighter and slightly thinner on one side WAY WAY better keyboard biggest downside of 2019 MacBook Pro is butterfly keyboard but it comes a 4 year extended warranty.

In my opinion 'd be very disappointed as I3 graphics probably a UHD 630 'd get worse performance than say...a 500 - 600 dollar HP since resolution is so much higher and Apples laptop cooling always makes it slower than other makes.
You'll have a bad time a dual core MacBook air in 2020.
AVOID MacBook Airs. Buy 2020 MacBook Pros instead.

I have a G2-mech 15 which I’m assuming is similar. Fan speed and noise for me for typical use is fine and would be appropriate for a classroom setting. However it does get hot and max out temps around 90C under heavy load gaming. My screen failed and needed be replaced just after my one year warranty ran out which i suspect was just from heat cooking internal components. After replacing screen issue appeared again but intermittently. I was able undervolt my cpu and gpu lower temps significantly and issue has subsided. I also game fan maxed out which is pretty loud. Max temps were 90C pre undervolt and 75-80C now.
Are referring this Eluktronics MAG-15 Slim ?

I have Eluktronics MAG-15 2070 max-q gpu option I bought it when it was released. has a button for 3 settings power saver gaming and gaming eluktroboost. also let's choose between different fan options for each power setting. In power saver mode there's near-zero fan noise I don't notice it at all. Now when have either of gaming power settings on and load up an intensive game fans ramp up for sure. That being said there's not many options out there that have comparable weight/size that do not noise when put under load same/similar performance. laptop never overheats it always stays at a normal temperature. is a great laptop for taking class because of it's light weight and size. it's less than five pounds which is great. Also since bezels are quite thin it's footprint is much smaller than other 15.6 in screen laptops I've had in past which makes it easy put in/out of a backpack. Also battery life is great it last at least a couple of hours 're gaming. But for just light web browsing/homework assignments/notes it last around 9 hours which is great 're going be in class/on campus for several hours. power brick is 230w and a pretty big pain carry it but I usually don't because battery life is very good.

I don't know that much myself but from what I've gathered recently looking buy one myself a very important metric is screen quality. 's thing 're going be staring at all time so be sure get a decent one especially because that's where budget laptops tend cut corners. Make sure your brightness is at least 300 nits Make sure it's not a TN screen Get a decent color gamut and accuracy 70% or better I believe Most other things are dependent on your specific needs. Laptops are usually alot about balance. Sure 4k is nice but your battery suffer. A 2080 is nice but your battery suffer. Screen- screen quality should be an IPS screen 300nit and above being acceptable. As color accurate as possible. 4K screens are pretty but pull too much battery power so it's not usually worth it in such a small screen. 1080p is fine 60hz are not gaming. CPU- Get a capable CPU. AMD Ryzen offers 8 cores for same power usage as Intel's 4 cores? Get Ryzen. RAM- 8GB MINIMUM preferably in a dual channel configuration. This give more bandwidth from RAM CPU. 16GB or above is ideal. GPU- most gamers love high framerates for smooth gameplay especially in first person shooters.amd and Intel both have integrated graphics which are tiny chips that run display and play games. At least Vega iGPU game. Intel iGPU is a joke 't game for most part. Those are low powered basic iGPU. Dedicated GPU are additional bigger graphics chips that are more powerful and push alot of frames. For gamers and content creatovideo editors. A dedicated GPU is a must because software uses graphics card help do work. don't game hard or don't due heavy video editing get by an integrated GPU. Storage laptops should only have SSDs nowadays. HDD have mechanical moving parts and use alot more power those parts move than an SSD which is just a chip. Typically 256GB should be minimum. Build quality- this is up consumer typically a metal or aluminum body as it's more sturdy but usually more expensive. Plastic sturdy laptop chassis work too but feel cheaper BUT they are more cost effective. Some users care about plastic feeling? Others not but either way it should be sturdy and not flex too much. Ports- should have as many ports as they give usually high end models have multiple USBC or thunderbolt ports but medium ones are now using USBC along USB A and HDMI ports. Try have at least 1 USBC and 1 USBA 3.1 and up port.

Throttling is when your laptop basically forces CPU slow down conserve battery and keep laptop cool as well as keep laptop as quiet as possible. Throttling issues happen when laptop unsuccessfully throttles causing a loss in performance or does it too much that it's noticeable and doesn't offer a good experience. Most reviews don't say anything about throttling issues but hear a lot about it then I would say that it's not a great thing have in a laptop so steer clear. As far as fans go I'm pretty sure reviewers said that fans would turn on noticeably for short periods of time but then would stay quiet for most part so I guess could say it's like a regular laptop for today's standards. Really depends on what ’re looking for. processor is going be your main workhorse for most tasks. i5/Ryzen 5 should be good for most part but ’re doing more intensive stuff and future proof yourself i7/Ryzen 7 would be a better choice. Also for Ryzen I would definitely get 4000 series huge step up from 3000 series. Intel hasn’t really changed much since 8th gen currently in 10th GPU is what ’re going for games or any graphic intensive stuff. ’re really trying game I would look at 1660ti minimum and RTX series 2060-2060 would all run current AAA games at a good frame rate. yo don’t that much gaming power then maybe a q640 or 1050 would be good or lower it’s just basic games run. Most dedicated GPUs be able run most creative software so could get a less powerful one than I listed above. although it gets more intensive may a better GPU like one for games Neither GPU or CPU be upgraded on laptops save for like Alienware a51 which runs for like 4k Ram is going be crucial in order run intensive games and more intensive software/big data sets. You could get away 8 but I would recommend at least 16 give yourself some wiggle room and future proof yourself. Dual channel ram 2 stocks gives better performance than single channel so be on lookout for that when purchasing. Ram is relatively cheap though so find a steal of a deal for a laptop without your desired amount of ram get 2 8gb sticks of ram for like 70 and it’s easy upgrade. Also cheaper for do yourself than it is upgrade Storage is important for speed too. NVMe is fastest. SSd still fast but not quite as fast as NVMe. HDD is slow and I would recommend against it unless your laptop also has a ssd that it use for your operating system so it boots up quick. A lot of laptops have extra storage bays though and storage is also cheap 1tb SSD be found for around 100 little more or less depending on brand. Screen is last real important conponent and it’s important because ’re going be staring at it all time. 1080p is pretty much minimum and go up 1440p your budget allows. 4K is cool too but I feel that 4K and 1440p isn’t that important on a laptop because screens are pretty small. 1440p would be great have though although it may be pricier than it’s worth. Higher resolutions also drain your battery faster too so keep that in mind. Next is screen refresh. 60hz is ok get a lower end graphics card as might not push that boundary much anyway. I would recommend a 120 or 144hz screen instead though as it makes your display look great and play less intensive games at higher fame rates and high end games as well GPU is strong enough. Battery life isn’t always great on gaming laptops but most manufacturers post typical battery life so see what prefer. I like have more battery in case I’m not near an outlet but game won’t really be able on battery for more than an hour or 2 high capacity battery laptops. Thermals are important but usually fix that software and lotions run warm for most part anyway compared desktops. I would recommend getting a laptop some fan control but that is pretty typica in gaming laptops and not so much on other types Then it’s pretty much preference. Metal builds last longer and are more premium. Keyboards aren’t necessarily subjective but it is still up your preference. Most trackpads have windows drovers so they’ll act pretty much same but some are better than others. Pretty easy fix a mouse though. Weight/form factor is whatever it be.

Fun story about those remotes I worked in a college IT department and kept getting called down a classroom for an issue classroom lighting system. lights could be turned on and off a touch panel on “smart cart” combination of computer document camera dvd/vcr and for some reason lights would turn on and off in middle of class. No other room had ever had that problem. No one could figure out what was going on until one of our interns realized that classroom was only one a Mac. We decided try investigate other things that might be different about that room. Our intern came my office one day and said “Hey I know this is going sound crazy but lighting issue is caused by this Mac remote.” Sure enough that remote used same signal that touch panel used control lights. Mystery solved. We threw that damn thing in garbage. TLDR That Mac remote was interfering our classroom lighting system.

I gotcha about saving money. I went 16GB and then returned it after I found out that Final Cut Pro needs 32GB for optimal performance. Depends on your use case. Do an i9? You'll list your use case for anyone give proper advice.

To add everyone else’s comments which I agree are doing Uni work? Does that mean Safari web browsing Microsoft Word PDF reading and annotation? so then any computer do that. 8GB RAM is enough but I would keep it safe at 16GB RAM. ’re pushing a lot of data video data or RAW photo data and do it daily then ’ll 32GB RAM. 16GB is enough but 32GB give your CPU more overhead for those kinds of tasks. only do occasional photo or video project 16GB is enough. do only occasional video/photo projects 6-core i7 is enough. Basically start base configuration i7/16GB RAM/512GB/Storage/5300 GPU. This is overkill for Uni work but a fine computer none less. Now ask yourself what daily task necessitates upgrades and go from there.

main big excuse get 10th gen is gaming capabilities. 2nd would be video editing. 8th gen is otherwise just as capable for a massive price savings. This guy recently did a comparison that might have info are looking for.

A common misconception is that MBA has better processor for being 10th gen. This is because of Intel's horrible branding. MacBook Air uses Intel's low power Y-series chips that run at 7W-15W and lower clocks. MacBook Pro although they are 8th gen use U-series chips that run at 15-25W and outperform 10th Gen Air except in Graphics performance where any 10th gen chip blows previous chips out of water thanks new Gen11 GPU . Also thermals matter a lot in real world performance and a properly cooled 8th gen outperform a 10th gen where heatsink isn't connected fan.
MBP all way. new air is garbage i7 it absolutely cannot cool itself and throttle and ramp fan all way up start multitask or so demanding tasks.

MacBooks keep active after its lid closes. 's called Standby mode and only fall sleep after a certain amount of time. Even during sleep it keep doing regular maintenance tasks and internet syncing. 's a feature called Power Nap On a new machine it easily get a lot of works done during standby since it needs time finish things like cache and log cleanup VM paging file system check spotlight index app updating photo music syncing Time Machine backup etc etc. 're suspecting that your battery is malfunction turn off Power Nap and change sleep mode and standby delay

Technically it shouldn't happen. 1. Browsers always notify user when something is downloaded it's automatically triggering download from Javascript codes. 2. Even accidentally downloaded malware it's only a bulk of file on disk and do nothing without activating it. 3. There is no known way for Javascript codes in a web page launch processes outside of browser. However in real world people always find undiscovered bugs and glitches in OS and apps and sometimes these be used exploit against security defense of your computer. We called these type of attacks Zero-day attack which means rest of us only know existence of this vulnerability after being attacked. And since these vulnerabilities is previously unknown it's almost impossible defend these attacks from nowhere. That's why security measure of a computer system is shifting from install anti-virus setup firewall how fast patch security hole in past decade. 's very crucial keep your system update--date. Attackers and software venders are playing cat-and-mouse game eternally and consumers only catch up them.

Hi First idea I've had similar issues my mac having worse and worse wifi reception over past 2-3 years. Turns out flats around me are upgrading routers and wifi interference is getting worse as more people have powerful routers blasting wifi into my flat. Is your wifi network 2 4 or 5 ghz? possible use a 5ghz network avoid excessive interference. You check this by holding alt and hovering over wifi icon in top right of your mac desktop. Here click open wireless diagnostics then when a window pops up go top left and click window. You should see an option Scan. Click this and do a scan. How many networks do see? sort by RSSI is your network showing lowest negative number? -30 means better signal than -80 for example. Let me know! see networks here that have similar RSSI numbers your network they're on same channel and frequency then might adjust your wifi through your router. My tactic is narrow channel width of my wifi there's lots of interference. Say default width is 40Mhz but this means that might overlap other wifi networks and get bad signal stability. Lower it 20 Mhz and 'll lose some connection speed but gain stability. Second idea Not sure about air but macbooks usually have wifi antennas in their displays a small coax cable connecting antenna logic board. This cable run through hinge of display and has a change slowly degrade as open/close your laptop. I'd unscrew bottom of laptop and see it looks worn. I have similarly bad reception my retina macbook. I have a few spots in house where wifi works great due low interference narrow channel width I set up in my router. However I go farther interference from other wifi networks throw me off my wifi. Ultimate solution wire up. Get an ethernet cable and run it from your router your desk and get an ethernet mini-displayport or ethernet thunderbolt adapter depending on which connector your air has .

are using a single router? or a mesh network? and is house a single level multi level brick? as those cause interference at longer ranges. while 5Ghz is a faster connection interference due environmental factors be more prevelent on 5ghz 2.4 has a little easier time going longer distance. issue sound 2 fold. since 're having wifi connection issue MULTIPLE devices at least know its THE NETWORK and not your MBA for that issue. since said yours was having trouble connecting hotspots provided they were in close proximity could have issues wifi SETTINGS. x200B

I JUST made this similar switch a few days ago. And let me put TL DR upfront TL DR OS X is a drastically less mature and capable desktop experience vs Windows 10. Ok so that bombshell out of way. I sold both my gaming laptop and desktop and grabbed a new Macbook Pro 16 Larger screen and better gaming on 5500m Debating returning it for a base 2020 MBP 13 as I do not really extra power cause I game Shadow and Stadia. Anyways overall learning mac stuff has been fun and interesting. VMware fusion experience is DRASTICALLY cleaner than anything I have used on Windows. BUT not as capable in some areas. Like 't present 16 threads VM as 16 cores. WHY? . Now be clear I got this mainly for MUCH better laptop experience Apple hardware and features offer. track pad and Battery handling is SO much better than any Windows PC. Like playing games on trackpad is not just possible I did it for an hour and it was a pretty 'not shit' experience in Destiny2! Stadia . Here are things OS X totally FAIL at vs Win10. - Multi Display handling - Connecting and disconnecting displays. - Updates and patches. - Arranging windows. - Swapping out windows. - Swapping between 2 windows. - Waking from sleep. - Re-installing OS. - Re-paring a bad patch. - Apps crash and it is a PAIN deal vs a Win10 crash. - over zealous security preventing from doing lots of little things. Remember early days of Vista UAC... that but worse. We are talking 20 minutes of OS adjustments and BIOS changes do something as simple as apply an image an SD card for a raspberry pi. and then get undo all of those things re-secure it. And those are just my issues in 4 days. - So lets start multi screen. You cannot turn off extra displays unless power them down or unplug them. - Connecting a display take a long time recognize ever. - Updates are like Windows XP days. Forever download and 40 minutes apply. - Arranging windows is a horrid experience Microsoft patented tech and solution in OS X is horrendous are used it in 10. - Working between multiple windows is a joke as click interact window vs Windows 10 which is aware of what window work on most of time by simply mousing over it. Something as simple as pausing a youtube video in another window requires 2-3 clicks. small but HYPER unnecessary! I take a 10 year old garbage PC and have windows 10 up and running on it in about 20-30 minutes. a High end PC be up and running from a blank disk in 10-15 minutes A clean install on a top end mac takes 1-2 hours! - Waking from sleep is a crap shoot. forgets what is plugged in changes main display loses displays loses mouse. is a NIGHTMARE! I just told it NEVER sleep except in laptop only mode. - has failed install updates TWICE! and took an hour repair both times. resulting in some apps failing launch and thus how I discovered how bad clean install process is. Aaaaaaaand. None of these are stopping me from wanting keep going. Using windows in a VM in unity mode gives me a DRASTICALLY improved desktop experience. And bootcamping into windows for other usability issues. is fine. do go mac. Save your receipt / get it from a place a friendly return policy. Cause OS X is no where near as smooth as Windows 10 in MANY areas. Sadly. when it comes basic desktop experience. Windows 10 just works. EDIT Yes so far Laptop experience has been totally worth all of these issues and learning experiences. IF I was desktop only though.... I would not go mac.

In short yes in long term there is a penalty. Buy 256 are really sure never be close its limit capacity. SSDs have a specific amount of times that each block be written before becoming an unusable block. SSDs internal controllers try balance this by writing into blocks that have less amount of writes count they do this try maintain an uniform wear of all blocks. Bigger SSD drives have higher expectancy lifetime because they have more blocks distribute data into and wear less individual blocks. Also as an SSD goes full it speed goes down because of an extra effort needed by controller do its job when writing. Personally my 256GB “died” during an MacOS update I suspect because was almost full most of time and blocks wear too much. 512 is doing better for my professional needs.

I answered a very similar question about this on Ask Different recently. You oversubscribed power on USB bus. Those bus powered “hubs” use cheapest components read that as most inefficient and they’re being asked be a converter from DisplayPort HDMI an ethernet port and whatever else USB device that gets plugged into it. My recommendation since that many peripheral devices were needed was go CalDigit TS3 Thunderbolt dock. Yes. You’re referring it as a USB-C dock which is incorrect. USB-C is just physical port type not actual connection. This is a Thunderbolt dock connected Thunderbolt/USB-C port. Being that it’s thunderbolt ’re now connecting over PCIe bus and using a totally separate source of power. Those little hubs are great for quickly attaching a device here and there. They’re not meant act as a replacement for a bona fide dock that turns your laptop into a desktop.

I'm an Apple authorised service technician and I've just probably seen too many hard disks going bad. And I also knew that HD failing take down Fusion Drive completely no chance of data recovery. So when I got my iMac in 2014 it had FD but I immediately reformatted it separate disks. I installed system apps and my profile on Flash Storage and stored big data such as iTunes photo libraries videos and DVD rips on large HD. I saved up and a year later I replaced 1 TB HD 2 TB SSD and upgraded memory 32 GB . still goes well and now I use Flash as a temporary drive i.e. for Downloads folder. Now 2014 models had 128 GB flash. is not case any more - 1 TB FD has only 32 GB. I assume it would work OK for a while most often used system parts applications and user files such as caches fitted SSD partition. But soon experience slowdowns. I would just try avoid that last century tech spinning generation vibrations noise and extra heat but I had choose between 2 TB Fusion for 200 or 256 GB SSD for 100 I would probably go for ... 512 GB SSD for 300 🙂 especially it's going be a shared Mac where eventually family pictures and videos be. Avoid hard disks avoid FD go full in SSD. BTW there are cheaper external SSDs today on USB-C such as Samsung T5.

's a little bit confusing but things basically work out like this physical MacBook connector is USB-C. This port support both USB 3.1 10 Gbit/s and Thunderbolt 3 40 Gbit/s protocols protocol how data is sent over wire . Other PCs may or may not support both USB and Thunderbolt on their USB-C connectors. Your external HD uses USB 3.0 so should work just fine a regular USB 3.0 cable. Also note that it seems be a HDD rather than SSD so USB 3.0 speed is more than enough use HD at its full speed. Thunderbolt 3 cables are more expensive but also support higher speeds this is useful for things like eGPUs and some Thunderbolt based external SSDs. USB-C - USC-A adapters needed should be cheap but ensure that they support USB 3.0/3.1.

Ice lake 10th gen 10nm has lower base and boost clocks than whiskey lake 8th gen 14nm because intel has a semi-broken 10nm process which they've been unable scale high clock speeds. However because 10nm needs less power get same work done it boost for longer within same thermal envelope so in practice it does actually perform better unless 're keeping CPU's pegged a sustained workload and cause it clock down base clocks which is hard do any real world workload . And because it is 10nm it has more room for additional transistors which intel has used beef up on-chip graphics. That's why gpu is a lot faster on ice lake than whiskey lake. 1. Screenshots mechanism is changed. Now a screenshot delay for 5 seconds before it's actually saved as a file so that interact capture data annotate on it or transfer other apps without saving as a file. And after it's actually saved as a file sometimes it have another random delay before it shows un on desktop. Read 2 for explanation why delay. 2. 's normal that a newly created file take several seconds before it shows on desktop because each individual file icon on desktop is not just a plain data block but a dynamically changing window . Each single file be monitored as a individual tracking handler in WindowServer system service. So it's actually not a good practice have a lot of files on desktop because each file takes up some system resources both memory and CPU. 3. Recent Finder window is result of Spotlight search. won't change until spotlight index is updated. 's designed for search for files quickly not a tool for managing files. You should go exact path that store these files instead. 4. As explained in 2 there be an inevitable delay before icon shows up on desktop. Sometimes delay would be quite long. force Finder update desktop press Shift CMD N create a new folder on desktop.

I could provide links but it's best contact Apple Support so they remove Catalina off server for and put back OS your Mac shipped . They may charge for phone call don't have Applecare Plus. don't do that then may go through these long steps from this link. Honestly I would recommend ever try out a new OS it's best create a partition on your drive and install it there so test it your apps. 's a very bad idea blindly upgrade a new OS version over your current setup. BTW Time Machine restore only bring back a previous version of Catalina. For example your original install was Catalina 10.15.3 and upgraded 10.15.4 then Time Machine restore back 10.15.3 but it does not backup an entire OS only files.

Honestly it’s a preference thing. Apple care is basically limited warranty for three years plus two accidental coverages... Limited warranty portion cover for three years in case of any hardware failure and as long as there is no physical or liquid damage do not pay anything get it fixed. Accidental coverage has two tiers screen damage and any other damage... meaning physically/liquid damage your screen have pay a deductible 129 in Canada get a new screen. ANY other physical/liquid damage no matter how small or big Apple care limit cost 320 in Canada . For example spilled water on Mac and now it needs new top case screen battery and motherboard ... without Apple care are looking at easily over 1k in cost but Apple care maximum pay is 320 again in Canada To sum up keep two things in mind 1 Are careful your device or clumsy? clumsy Apple care is good value 2 Remember at end of day no matter who makes product. ’s an electric product and there is always a chance of failure. there is a hardware failure after first year are responsible for cost have look up deductible cost for accidental damage where are Hope this kinda clears it up a bit and helps a decision.

I'm pretty sure don't understand how use 16 in terms of battery. has a dedicated GPU and when it's activated by certain apps it drain battery because it's in high performance mode. I have 16 and I get full quoted 11 hours battery when used properly. There are only 2 major things that are causing battery drain and possibly a 3rd one. I have a 16 MBP AMD 5500 8GB card. 1 issue is AMD dGPU. drains battery. Period. 2 issue are apps being used that activate dGPU. Here is my short list of apps that are doing this. Chrome. Until recently it activated dGPU but has been fixed but it’s still a major resource hog and drains battery. Final Cut Pro X activates dGPU. Apple's Photos app activates dGPU. Adobe's Creative Suite . Resource hog and activates dGPU. Pixelmator photo editor. Activates dGPU. Connecting MacBook any external monitor activates dGPU. iMovie activates dGPU. Bootcamp. Running Bootcamp'd Windows works only on dGPU and there's no way switch it Integrated Graphics. Playing most games activates dGPU. These apps cannot run smoothly using Intel Integrated Graphics because MacBooks dedicated graphics like AMD 5000 series ship lower grade Intel Integrated Graphics. 13 MacBooks come better Intel Integrated Graphics run these apps since they don't ship a more powerful dGPU. Lastly 3rd reason for battery drain but not as major as dGPU is keeping screen brightness above 70%. 're using auto brightness control then this may not affect battery unless 're using it outside or in uncontrolled lighting. Without fail I get 11 hours of battery on my 16 MBP when I'm using apps that don't activated dGPU such as Safari and Apple Music. 's best for people verify dGPU is activated. Apple Menu-About this Mac. Intel UHD Graphics 630 and AMD Radeon 5000 Series GPU are listed then app are using drain your battery. 're unsure which ones then close all your apps and launch each one and verify dGPU is activated. Lastly leave these apps open and just shrink them into dock or close their windows they are still keeping dGPU activated so still experience battery drain when 're using basic apps like Apple's office suite. There is nothing wrong your 16 MBP's battery or computer or system management controller. These battery complaints have been going on for several years MacBooks that have dGPU's. More apps today are using dGPU so it's not always easy achieve advertised battery life. absolutely use these apps at a constant it's best plug in Mac for long sessions

I just seen error received. Try these steps trouble shoot. Go Utilities and click Terminal. Opening Terminal from macOS Utilities Type following command and hit Enter. Type date This command result in display of date which system currently has been set . might be reset 2001 for some arbitrary reason therefore we set it right date. To do this type following command and hit Enter. Type date -u month day hour minute year Two-digit numbers based on UTC should be replaced every bracket. You see below how command should look like according your current time and date – October 30th 2019 01 15. UTC is used instead of other timezones avoid trouble. Just enter it exactly like this Type date -u 1030011519f Check set date and time by running first command again. error should be fixed now. Copy and paste these commands avoid typos.

To avoid any problems when using cables keep in mind one simple rule bending radius should be minimum 10x cable's diameter. This is recommended by many cable manufacturers and also in various textbooks or technological encyclopedias. This is also needed since Apple cables are composed internally of several wires deserving different purposes - e.g. we find out some wires for data exchange along two supply wires and those are smaller diametethin isolation making them more vulnerable bending issues.

I recently upgraded a Late 2012 iMac i.e. first of really thin iMacs where screen is held glue instead of magnets . old hard drive had gotten so slow it was nigh unusable. I thought opening it up and putting it back together would be hard part. That turned out be relatively easy. Instead hard part was restoring my data from my Time Machine backup. First I tried restore from Time Machine via Recovery Mode but that resulted in a system that froze during startup. Then I tried recover directly from old HDD via USB but that didn't work at all. So anyone who wants upgrade an SSD and then recover your data from Time Machine way I finally got it working was by reinstalling Mac OS on SSD and then running Migration Assistant.

That's normal. Batteries fluctuate. percentage is just your current max battery charge divided by rated max battery charge.
's likely just calibrating over time. 'll plateau then eventually start drop as months/years go by.

Yes ’re right. All battery related values ’ve ever seen are only estimations. There isn’t really a gage on battery telling percentage number of remaining charges. Device keeps tracking battery usage including voltage changes temperature current usage and lifetime since it’s first powered and calculate approximate value of remaining charges and max capacity based on a chart which is derived from spec and statistics. That’s why ’ll see battery stuck at 100% for hours and drops like free fall after it hits 99%. That’s why fast charging be slowed down when battery is 80% full. And that’s why iPhone enable low power mode when battery is aging. Because we ’t get accurate situation of battery.

Agree everyone suggesting SnazzyLabs on Youtube. Some very helpful videos! Some things I wish I’d have known when I first switched 1. People recommend a lot of add-on tools for improving gesture control window management etc. Ignore that for now! Most people benefit from these but explore what Mac offers first. Play around gestures hot corners and mission control and find some settings that feel good and work well for . After a couple of weeks when really know what your Mac ’t do out of box there are a ton of good tools out there fill in gaps. 2. Command Space pulls up Spotlight and lets search your Mac easily open apps etc. find yourself using it but also find it limited check out Alfred for a search bar customize and program functions . 3. work audio might eventually find someone recommending SoundFlower as a way solve a problem recording / rerouting system audio. Do not do it unless absolutely have — it be a mess remove from your system and is notorious for causing more problems than it solves. 4. Install AppTrap it’s available by Homebrew — it’s a simple utility that ensures all relevant files are deleted when remove an application. 5. Command Delete let delete files. Function Delete behaves like Delete on a PC reverse backspace . 6. options for Keyboard in System Preferences are robust as hell. You set text replacements customize shortcuts and create new shortcuts for any app. This is often overlooked but one of my favorite native features in macOS. is also where toggle autocorrect have any issues it. 7. find yourself frustrated way media keys work aka expect it pause your music so watch a YouTube video but instead it is play/pausing YouTube video and not your music install Mac Media Key Forwarder. You set it prioritize iTunes or Spotify instead of controlling whatever media is active on screen. 8. At some point find yourself running out of storage and may find that “System Storage” is taking up way more space than feel it should. this happens go straight SnazzyLabs — he has a great video on this and honestly I don’t know a MacBook user who hasn’t run into this problem over course of years of use.

What on earth happend? You reinstalled Catalina as a new system for multiple times without wiping out hard drive first. How I fix this mess? 1. Make Time Machine backup 2. Boot into Recovery Mode 3. Generally yes There are various modes of sleep a Mac go into. At this point your question only describes fact your laptop screen goes sleep but this is different from your computer actually going sleep. Regardless of your settings and assuming your MacBook Pro has a continuous power source then a system event such as copying a large amount of data continue occur various parts of your Mac go sleep.1 This is because your Mac is in middle of an action such as copying files it not go entirely into sleep mode e.g. your display may go sleep but your drives are still fully powered up for read/write purposes . In terms of speed at which data is transferred this be affected by a number of factors but in your scenario transfer rate should not be impacted. Of course 're copying a large amount of data it is recommended have your MacBook Pro plugged into an AC power source. For more information on your Mac's sleep capabilities may refer following content Use Energy Saver settings on your Mac macOS Sierra Optimize energy settings for portable computers About Wake on Demand and Bonjour Sleep Proxy

GPU - Every 27 iMac comes a discrete graphics card which already puts it above 13 MacBook Pro have since only 16 get discrete GPUs afaik . Vega 48 is overkill unless do heavy 4K editing. You start three 2TB drives. Put all your photos on Drive 1. Sync Drive 1 Drive 2 so your photos are also on Drive 2. Sync Drive 1 Drive 3 so all your photos are also on Drive 3. Put Drive 2 in safe-deposit box in bank. Continue adding photos drive 1. Continue syncing Drive 1 Drive 2. Every 2 weeks 1 month swap Drive 2 and Drive 3 at bank and keep syncing Drive 1 whichever of other two have on hand. This way always have an offsite backup and are never more than 2 weeks a month behind should lose BOTH of your on-site drives. And THEN sync everything a cloud service anyway.

So macOS purposely grab “stuff” and toss it into RAM. cache in RAM all kinds of data so that quickly access it. also take some and allocate it for itself - this show up as “used” though it’s just technically being reserved for whatever needs it next. This way millisecond it’s needed macOS already has it allocated and ready go. That’s just how it’s designed. In “Activity Monitor” app there’s a chart at bottom labeled “Memory Pressure” - this is where look. As long as that’s green ’re all good. I'm going quote an answer I posted from a similar question. What ’re probably referring is inactive memory which is memory in RAM that was once needed but not anymore. Say in case opened Microsoft Word did a few things and then closed app. MacOS predict likelihood may use this application again within a certain timeframe. This concept is known as ‘temporal locality’ and so application start quickly again because data still exists in memory. As there is a competition for memory resources by other applications MacOS allocate resources by removing some of inactive memory allow memory be stored in active memory memory currently being used by applications . This is a fairly old article but it’s a good read based on topic Keep in mind too that shouldn't really pay attention memory usage provided by CleanMyMac. Instead look at Activity Monitor's Memory Pressure. This memory pressure shows how efficiently resources are being provided your processing needs. Green is good. Amber is okay. Red is bed. red should indicate that memory resources are scarce.

Look at your activity monitor. Sort it by Memory so it show most greedy at top. Is there something or multiple things that are using bulk of it? I have found that some tasks stay open running though I think they're closed. You end task from activity monitor. kernel task Is one that kills me. doesn't take that many apps there's just one that's greedy.

That's exactly how a modern operating system should do in memory management. Because unused RAM is wasted RAM . All modern operating systems have implement dynamic virtual memory that use all physical RAM AND hard drive at same time as memory space for user application. guidance of such design demands OS do two things 1. Fill up physical RAM as much as possible. 2. Avoid unnecessary changes memory allocation. Since a modern application frequently request and release memory from system it's waste of time rearrange overall memory allocation every time. OS tend keep released memory still associated original application that requested it as a cache space so that when application requests for memory again bet it it be allocated in no time. OS dynamically estimate activity of each application and determine when these preserved memory be released. In macOS this estimation is called Memory Pressure measured from various factors. Generally most people find a system kernel processes called WindowServer takes a lot of CPU and memory process. That's because WindowServer is bridge between application and graphics hardware. When an app wants draw something on screen WindowServer is one that takes demands from app and tells graphics card what where and how draw it. So when have multiple apps many windows on screen or have a lot of files on desktop WindowServer stay in busy state all time.

For those who didn't see my original post on May 5th LINK I am spray painting a 13 Unibody MacBook Pro in Satin Black. Journey so far Completely gutted shell Then prep work begins. I sanded down all parts started 120grit then moved on 240 and finished 400. I then filled in all scratches and dents as best I could Then I sanded it down 240 then 400grit and it is basically ready for primer I decided best way paint them would be hang them from ceiling that way I could paint both sides of them at same time. So I used my loft space paint them I gave them 4 light coats of Etch Primer leaving 30mins between coats was halfway through priming top case that I suddenly had idea remove DVD drive slot and Kensington lock as I was planning on using a 2nd hard drive in place of DVD drive anyway and I would regret it I didn't do it. So I took it down and filled in slots While I was waiting repaint top case I waited 24 hours for etch primer harden on other two parts then very lightly wet sanded it 400grit sandpaper give it a smooth finish. This is how I hung pieces from ceiling Masking tape and string I also masked areas where logic board makes ground bottom case I then proceeded paint Satin Black 4 light coats paint looked really patchy because of light coats and I was worried it was going look crap but I held out hope that Satin clear coat would fix that. While Black was hardening I finished priming of top case and it looked so much nicer DVD slot delete 24 hours later Black was ready clear coat and top case was ready sand. Top case primer sanded down 3 light coats of Satin clear coat followed by a single heavier coat finish it off Satin clear coat made all difference and really made final finish so much better. insides look crap but 're never going look at them anyway final results for top and bottom panels There are a few imperfections and some dust that settled on paint but I'm pretty happy final finish. turned out much better than I was expecting I'm honest! goes show that put in prep results speak for them selves. top case is currently in loft after having 4 coats of Satin Black. 12pm tomorrow I be applying Satin Clear coat. Then 24 hours after that painting be finished. I'm currently waiting for a White Macbook Keyboard in mail which I be taking Key caps from and transferring them keyboard for this laptop. Which I think look awesome! I post next update when it is all complete!

You an installer cd/dvd wipe hard drive and reinstall system software

You a Mac OS install CD / DVD. Luckily readily find images on sites like Macintosh Garden or Macintosh Repository. Don’t try booting off USB as it won’t work without some extra tinkering and I never had much luck that personally. Burn image / images onto their disc / discs put disc in drive refresh boot picker screen pictured and should see a disc icon OS X logo. Click on that then arrow and should have Mac OS X Installer starting up. Images larger than 4.7GB must be burned a dual layer DVD-R. They won’t fit on a CD-R or a single layer DVD-R. Edit 02 iMac G4s support Mac OS X 10.1.3 Puma all way 10.4.11 Tiger depending on model. Don’t try installing 10.5 Leopard unless it’s one of later machines. You also enter Disk Utility and wipe hard drive before reinstalling Mac OS. There should be an option in menu bar which brings up Disk Utility - it’s name varies depending on version of Mac OS X ’re installing though I think. Make sure ’re formatting it as Mac OS Extended Journaled .

Wait a minute... 6TB of data in Outlook ? Are serious ? I'm not sure how he handle this because Outlook is apparently not designed for such task. 's a GTD Get Things Done and groupware tool but not a knowledge base nor a good journaling tool not mention data storage. it's real then he must have some SERIOUS PROBLEMS in his workflow. Outlook is infamous for locking up all its data in proprietary repository and there is no way change repository path which is located at /Library/Group Containers/UBF8T346G9.Office . Moving these data between machines would be difficult because 're supposed use Outlook built-in archive export/import feature for this task. I'm not sure simply copying files within that folder work. A far as I know some people had tried move files somewhere else and symbolic lines old position but Outlook just ignore it and recreate a new profile instead. So best solution would be manually archive and export every time. For a long term solution first he must learn NOT put all data in same stash because it means that 'll go though 6TB of data for only 1MB changes inside that way. Try get a profession knowledge base / journaling tool like DEVONThink and classify data into different categories. have trouble making categories at least do this Ongoing Project Reusable Resources Recently closed projects Archives So that only keep ongoing project on local drive and this should drastically reduce data size that be synced every time. TL DR whole point is minimize data that needs be synced every time. he do this then storage media isn't really important.

Thoughts on my current XPS 15 9500 Pros ★ No Coil Whine!!! I used own a XPS 13 9360 and coil whine is always most annoying issue that I faced especially when I am in a quiet room. Finally Dell engineers was able solve issue! ★ New mold. By adding 16 10 screen ratio and do some modification on vent and ports this machine is finally built for consumers! ★ Low heat. I thought 10875H would be generating a lot of heats but machine stay mostly cooled when I ran Path of Exile. When I tested R20 fan was not running at peak. Dell was able engineer it very nice and is just as expected! ★ Four sided InfinityEdge Display! 16 10 really made huge different and I compared it Zbook Studio G5 G5 was just not enough for me. By way Dell also put Windows hello facial recognition into ultra thin bezel on top which is amazing! ★ Long battery life. I think it might because I chose Full HD and that is why it last for more than 8 hours. Not sure how long would 4K last. ★ 60W PD charging. show that I am connected a slow charger but it still charges laptop when I was running Cinebench R20. ★ Powerful Performance. I was surprised that performance is similar my Ryzen 7 1700x. Cinebench R20 shows that single core performed better than Ryzen 7 1700x. Cons. ☆ All type C ports. ’s good that it comes DA20u about half size of DA200 without ethernet and VGA port but there is no Type A or HDMI. Also there are only 3 type c ports while xps 15 2in1 has four. ☆ No dedicated microphone mute key. I see that F9 does not have other command on it. I hope Dell would add mute key on F9. ☆ Page up and Page down is integrated. For those of use a lot of pg up and pg dn like me might get used it two hands.

I suspect that Dell wants either reset model numbers since their scheme led them down a cul de sac or they be able clear out older models and stock by making it unclear which model is newest. When they release a new model it takes time for production process ramp up become affordable and market demand grow. So they inevitably still have a few months supply of previous model in pipeline and probably not made yet. But people typically newest model meaning they have struggle shift older models which are more profitable when sold at full price but loss makers have be sold off in bulk bulk purchases for clearance.

Lol why TF ur disabling Turbo Boost man that's like throwing your money out of window! Anyway undervolt settings are different for each user because none of CPU/GPU are made same welcome silicon lottery! . Basically gotta figure out undervolt setting for your laptop by yourself. Also your laptop has latest BIOS that may prevents from undervolting due plundervolt so downgrade older BIOS necessary. For CPU First turn back on Turbo boost and download throttlestop. For your starting point set CPU and cache -125mv and use TS Bench test CPU's stability. 1 of 3 tests give back error then have dial back undervolt setting maybe -100mv or whatever till tests no longer produce errors. tests don't produce errors at -125mv setting then increase it -130 -135 -140 etc. until your laptop BSOD. trick is undervolt as much as possible but undervolting too much is just as bad as disabling turbo boost. For GPU Undervolting GPU is a bit trickier but often time not necessary because Turing GPUs are easy cool unless your laptop sucks donkey balls. For this MSI afterburner. Tutorial on how use it is over all internet so just look it up. I think 925mv is lowest should go. After done toying your system just perform a stress test using this guideline here and let it run for 20-30 minutes. won't kill your laptop since it's as bad as playing AAA titles at ultra settings maybe lighter in some cases . Make sure power management/fan setting is set max so I see best your laptop give. In HWInfo64 focus on CPU Package PoweGPU Package Power supported . should sustain 45W/80W respectively while running at 85-90 Celcius/70-80 Celcius respectively. Obviously zero sign of thermal throttling. Any significant deviation means your laptop needs physical care such as repaste dust out fans whatever else. your stress test result examined either PM me screenshot of your stress test or join Suggest A Laptop discord.

I recently got a g7 7590 that had better hardware than yours but same issues fps. I've built desktops for years so I had a bunch of monitoring apps troubleshoot. My laptop was reaching 100C during bootup so anytime a program would run there was extreme thermal throttling and power throttling. You get realtemp 3.70 and run realtempgt for temps. Look up how run an elevated command prompt get it start windows. Also go get Intel XTU and run benchmark quickly. show whether have thermal or power throttling. Hwinfo64 is another good monitoring app that reads way more sensors than necessary. What check that though is what peaks and where your processor clocks stop and your gpu clocks stop. For example when run gta 5 computer hits 100c before max performance it thermal throttle dells proprietary software try and keep temps down but it doesn't work as intended because fans take too long run. have a major overheating problem then start a chat Dell do a remote session and show them temps by opening up a program. that's case it's either a hardware issue or bad thermal paste application at factory. Other things try that I've read about my machine would be undervolt throttlestop or Intel xtu reinstall windows get all Dell bloatware and power management software out create your own power plans that best match how use machine.

read details of recent bios update just did intel removed ability undervolt. no undervolt awful thermal management in xps laptops lots of overheating which lead consistently high fan speeds. i personally downgraded my bios after finding out my undervolts no longer worked and go into bios settings upon boot restore back defaults or else it keep undervolt restriction from 1.16 update. find videos online or search google for others dealing this issue. id recommend opening your laptop and cleaning it using pressurized air carefully . sure unplug battery when open it be sure dont damage any of components incidentally. there are thermal problems your laptop id recommend repasting thermal paste and replacing thermal pads as well as adding thermal pads VRM's transfer heat case of laptop. i did this recently and saw a 20deg celcius decrease in overall temps. im now down 40deg C idle and 60-70deg C while gaming. GTA V runs 70 fps high settings peak CPU temps of 75 usually between 68-70. xps lineup unfortunately has incredibly bad thermal throttling especially over time so it's worth looking into imo edit i know said dont undervolt or repaste but are quite literally leaving yourself no significant options decrease temperatures rule out those off bat
