Why are asking all of this after having bought laptop already? I just don't it run extremely hot Laptops are designed run hot. A laptop being hot isn't a bad thing it's doing exactly what it is intended running as fast as possible up designated thermal limit. There is no product-life-threatening aspect of it running hot. Will it run hotter cover vents your legs while playing a game? yes. duh. But run it hot all day and that won't do anything adverse your device. I've probably logged over 400 hours on my 9570 doing 4k-video rendering where it's run flat-out for dozens of hours at a time. Nothing happens. I'm also wondering about portability You easily find out dimensions of what bought by looking online. Why didn't do this before buying it? XPS is designed be a portable and powerful laptop. 's not a gaming laptop those are far less portable. Is it a laptop? Yes. 's very portable. I've heard that these tend suffer from not best thermals and some throttling Why does this matter ? throttles under heavy load. So what? it's not going throttle while browsing watching movies or audio engineering. Will it throttle play a AAA game that absolutely maxes out computer? Yes. 's going run right up limit. As intended. Overwatch and Sims it play no problem at all. play Rise of Tomb Raider 1080p at 50fps. play Far Cry 4 5. play most AAA games from a few years ago.

Gaming shouldn't be an issue it'll get hot but that's every computer. 'll get a tad warm at most when doing simple web browsing. Using any laptop on a couch or bed get warmer than normal because when it's not on a flat surface air flow isn't optimal so give space for fans. Very portable device for a 15 .

That website is incorrect. Quadro RTX 3000 has equally as many shaders as does GeForce RTX 2060 in fact they are exactly same card I owned Quadro RTX 3000 albeit in thicker and heavier Precision 7530 here are some benchmarks vis-à-vis Quadro P3200 same card as notebook GTX 1060 mobile and Quadro RTX 5000 same card as desktop RTX 2080 SUPER . Open three orange spoilers for actual results. In fact Quadro RTX 3000 and 5000 perform worse than they're supposed because of neutered power limit compared desktop cards. RTX 5000 I currently own has 3072 shaders and 16 GB GDDR6 VRAM but 80 W power limit means it performs like a desktop RTX 2060 SUPER achieving little more than 18000 in Fire Strike Graphics. desktop RTX 5000 has as many shaders and as much VRAM and runs at a whopping 265 W TGP and destroys RTX 2080 in benchmarks. To answer your other questions Programming robot simulations lil' gaming and a lil' machine learning majority I do in cloud . This is precisely my use case. I run CUDA simulations write OpenGL D3D12 projects and am getting into 3D modelling rendering and ray-tracing too. I also play my fair share of games. AC Odyssey runs at high settings 60 FPS 1080p Witcher 3 runs at ultra settings 60-70 FPS 1080p Shadow of Tomb Raider runs at 50-60 FPS Ultra settings 1080p Control before DLSS 2.0 runs at high settings no ray-tracing at 45-60 FPS 1080p Kingdom Come Deliverance runs at high settings 45-60 FPS 1080p. This is a variety of games I am currently playing. Overall games are certainly playable at higher FPS turn down some settings and accept quality drop. I wouldn't buy Precisions just for Quadro but rather for incredible business-class customer support sure get ProSupport Plus Accidental Damage for 3 years at least and generally better QC and QA than XPS. They're exactly same chassis but Precision name is more important Dell. That said are bent on getting a 17 machine high performance why not get 7750 instead? You get options go up Quadro RTX 5000 upgrade memory displays SSDs M.2 WiFi cards name it...

Considering 'll be equally thermally constrained in both setups I doubt see much of a performance gain from Quadro RTX 3000 Mobile . all depends on how well Dell has tuned these GPUs as it's highly unlikely that be able hit 80W on GPU as well as 35-100W on CPU without crashing limits of cooling.

rtx 2060 and quadro rtx 3000 are same core TU106 quadro does not have more shaders or pipelines i'm not sure where got that info from. They are going perform nearly identically I would say how nvidia's boost works. Also killer 1650 is just a rebranded intel chipset it likely works good in linux killer no longer uses qualcomm for their wifi6 generation. Even then just buy an AX200/201 intel card for 20 really that instead. Just get XPS 17 precision has no advantages for your use case

Your title and wattage question is one thing. Not charging past 70% is something completely different. Either way regarding both wattage question and not charging past 70% answer is absolutely not . While slower charge cycles may help maintain your battery health still MUST USE THE POWER ADAPTER THAT YOUR SYSTEM REQUIRES . wattage is not only required for charging. ’s for running rest of your system CPU RAM graphics display etc. Do not use a lower wattage power adapter. Long answer Always fully charge your battery whenever plug it in. Never partially charge battery. When do plug it in charge wait until battery is fully charged before unplugging charger and using system on battery power again. Never use “express” or “fast” charge options in BIOS or in Windows. Always use slowest charge method that is available. Faster charge cycles wear a battery out quicker. battery is easily removable removing it entirely once it is fully charged while system is plugged and turned on keep battery from wearing. Systems pull power from both battery and AC power simultaneously while system is running hint this happens when use aftermarket or undersized power adapters so your best bet is simply disconnect battery or turn off charging this is at all possible. Most systems have a battery charge disable option. Do some research on how disable battery charging. do charge battery don’t do it while are using system. ’s always best charge battery whenever system is not in use so try not use system while battery is charging. use system remove battery or disable charging . Try wait until battery has discharged at least 20% before recharging it. Short charge/discharge cycles quickly wear out battery. ’s actually better fully discharge your battery before charging it again avoid those short discharge/charge cycles. You should also calibrate your battery once a month for heavy battery users or every other month use battery less often. Follow this link for detailed instructions on how properly calibrate your battery. As see proper battery charging techniques is only one step of many when it comes battery maintenance and maximizing performance. However please use adapter that your system shipped and do not use a lower wattage or aftermarket adapter or run risk of not only destroying your battery but also burning adapter and catching a fire. Simply don’t do it. And while we’re on subject of aftermarket power adapters let me say repeat do not use aftermarket or undersized power adapters or they turn your battery into an spicypillows
No I don't see why it would work that way. Wattage is a measure of rate of energy transfer i.e. capacity. A 130w power supply supply 130w but device only draw up what it needs function and no more.

on a 15 screen it for sure makes a difference. my current laptop is 14 UHD and while I tell difference resolution-wise from FHD version it's not a particularly noteworthy downgrade though lower brightness and color reproduction is noticeable . on a 13 machine I'd be hard-pressed tell difference at normal usage distance and harder-pressed recommend it as a worthwhile upgrade unless specifically it for work video editing digital artist photographer etc. - battery life hit is very noticeable I get 7-8 hours on my UHD same device an FHD display hit 10 easily and benefits are much less so.

I've had both FHD and 4K of XPS 7390 2 in 1 and I tell there is a difference. Small difference but it is there. I had 4K for 4 months and wanted change for FHD get more battery life. 4K screen has much more details its visible dont get fooled by online reviews that say its not noticable . 4K is better for visualising articles or webpages however watching videos its not really a big difference. However get really used FHD and I think trade off for battery life is so much worth it. never had a 4K display before go for FHD. battery life is a concern go for FHD. Otherwise go for 4K.

As another poster said try resetting BIOS default and then don't touch em. Defaults seems be only settings they actually test be working because ordinary custom settings would create long hangs on a variety of operations. 4. You try other versions of BIOS including earlier than what have but beware Dell Command Update utility trying patch it back version 're having problem and then more hangs . Seems be a lot of misunderstanding around what this rating means. 300 discharge/charge cycles amount of times fully drain then fully charge battery before capacity noticeably start degrade. ie 've gone through 250 cycles still expect have close full battery capacity. 400 or 500 cycles battery be far below 100%. This is pretty standard across industry across most devices. Notable exceptions are many mobile phones and some Apple products. I understand Dell and other OEMs also offer long-lifecycle batteries 1 000 cycle rating on their commercial products. 're really worried about battery longevity recommend disabling any 'fast-charge' settings. These along full discharges 0% degrade your battery at an accelerated rate.

I know cards some degree do share load I've always assumed my discrete graphics focused on heavier 3D lifting while integrated handled more of Windows Aero / Explorer load. That being said should see discrete card taking number crunching on. for some reason it isn't I think might sure that necessary configuration is made have system prefer that card. I'm not sure of verbiage on an ATI model as I have a NVIDIA card in all of my various systems. In NVIDIA it's something effect of Prefer High Performance Processor . Another possibility is thermal throttling occurring which should be able determine by getting Intel XTU and monitoring your card during gameplay. For me I had undervolt my Dell XPS 15 some degree for more stable performance. Additionally and this may be contentious I disable TurboBoost in BIOS. I find short burst of performance overpowers thermals on my Dell XPS and I'd rather have a steady clock speed and predictable thermal variables. Finally I found that I often had better performance using Dell drivers for video card. I know that is also somewhat sacrosanct in PC world and I don't do same thing on my Dell G5 gaming PC or on a Dell XPS or Alienware tower. For whatever reason I see better more predictable performance on my Dell XPS Dell provided ones. They seem update enough that I don't feel left behind and I run into far less problems. YMMV. Connected standby is consuming too much battery when machine is turned off completely. computer is in connected modern standby then it's not off. 's largely business as usual but screen disabled. Certain services shut off and hardware goes into a low power mode but it's still sitting there checking your email periodically listening for other notifications and generally doing stuff didn't actually when put it in suspend in first place. Microsoft claims a laptop stay in this mode for a week or more but my experience is that every Monday morning your battery be nearly dead. How am I sure machine was off? Either use Hibernate or Shut Down.

battery is degrading work Dell support. that's not it... Based on my fans also seem be running louder and more often I'm suspicious of some rogue application loading up your CPU all time. Open your task manager when machine should be idle but fans are running and identify process that's using most CPU. Regarding CPU usage under 10% 10% is measured against clock speed of your CPU. You should try undervolting. Download Intel XTU go core then go core voltage offset and then go down by -0.010v then do a stress test for 5 minutes. Keep going down by -0.010v and keep stress testing everytime go down until your system is unstable. Then go back up 0.010v and run a stress test for 30 minutes could stress for longer sure it is stable . That should be max undervolt. it is ever BSOD or is unstable again just go up by 0.010v again.

Cleaning fans regularly and thermal repasting is help your overheating issue

I had similar issue. Steps I took fix it. 1. Update BIOS and drivers latest. 2. Install Alienware Control and set thermal balanced and power ultra. 3. Reapply thermal paste CPU and GPU. Any decent paste do wonders. 4. Undervolt using throttlestop CPU and CPU cache -.125. might be able go lower depending on silicon. Watch Bob of all trades video on YouTube. 5. mount it on a laptop cooling pad or just get so.me airflow going in. I went from 90-100 degree 100% fan and constant thermal throttling 70-80 degree nirvana only occasional fan noise under stress test conditions. And performance is better now.

be basically everything. Software or hardware error. In my experience most BSODs are caused by hardware failures. Try reinstalling audio/webcam/video drivers or update bios.

issue is usually caused by a hard drive/driver corruption Try reinstalling/updating your graphic drivers doing a chkdsk and a full malware scan your preferred av except norton/mcaffe To do chkdsk open up command prompt eith administrator right then type in chkdsk /f /r press Y restart. Once chkdsk finished open up cmd administrator right and type in sfc /scannow this take a couple of minutes but this ensure that no drivesys file has been corrupted To update drivers open Run dialog Win R type in devmgmt.msc open drivers section right click graphic drivers click update drivers and follow update instructions. After this finishes just restart it doesnt do it automatically then test for BSOD. Hope this helps

Of 15 in 35xx line only goes up 32 gb ram 5540 goes up 64 gb ram 7540 goes up 128 gb ram big differences between these two are portability sustained performance and upgrades 5540 is smaller and lighter but that means that although it pack similar components as 7540 it overheats much more quickly and severely throttle performance in sustained hours processing. Power Limit Throttling is a function of CPU drawing more than it's rated power draw or VRM/other components exceeding thermal maximums. your thermals are in check and 've opened up CPU's power limits as far as firmware and/or XTU allow then there is nothing else do. For example have a 45W CPU and restriction on this chip is say 60W push it above 45W 60W chip tries draw more than 60W it'll Power Limit throttle and there's nothing do about it.

60-70 fps doesnt sound that bad. mine throttles CPU clocks down 800mhz and I get 2fps. thing chokes so hard I cant exit game. trick is keep cpu gpu and ambient temps down. They all affect one another so improving only one doesn't help much. Some things that helped me repaste cpu and gpu shaved near 20 degrees off peak load temps no joke undervolting cpu and igpu maybe another 5 degrees or so turn off turbo boost when gaming caps clocks at 2.80ghz but produces much less heat in a much more controlled manner undervolting dgpu now able hold a constant 70 degrees consistent 1800mhz dgpu clock speeds Set ultra performance under thermal settings in dell power manager allows fans run a bit harder Literally pointing a desk fan at laptop I really push it. Hello for information which computer? x200B Never keep standard battery charge parameters in BIOS modify them avoid a too deep discharge and a too high load. worst is when are on mains and parameters ins BIOS or Setup require that always charge battery. My parameters in BIOS or Setup because I am under Linux are never charge more than 85% and charge battery only from 50% of SOC on mains see also parameter critical charge action in Windows or Linux and set this parameter 15 or 20% of remaining SOC State of Charge in order avoid producing lithium dendrites which irreparably destroy battery slowly very slowly but definitively. From time time every 4-6 months change parameters obtain a full charge at 90-95% never 100% and discharge battery up threshold of 15-20% SOC depending on settings calibrate inevitable wear of Li-Ion battery in battery manager. Avoid use Rapid Charge too often. OK we have a battery that have a range of use of only 20% 85% on battery but it last longer except construction defect . My parameters mean that on mains as long as battery is not below 85% it never charges I plug in main AC LED charge indicator turns on but stops and it does charge it charges but stops at 85% max. I install lithium battery systems LFP or LiFePO4 technology and charge systems solar panels alternators and shore for sailing boats I know problem well LFP are more safe. For ThinkPad Lenovo and I believe HP charge is optimized in this way which means that batteries wear out much less quickly but computer seems not be able last longer on battery since range of use is less important. Dell and many other computers do not have this battery charge control software and hardware. Sorry for my english I'm French.

Unfortunately XPS 15 bragging-right specs listed at Dell sales pages don't include cooling capacity which is unfortunately a poor match heat dissipation of listed chips when put a serious long-tem workload. Certain hardware in form of heatpipes and cooling fins is lacking. XPS 15 is a thin-and-light and throttling is essential keep it from meltdown. As notice there are guides how it cope gaming loads better. Repasting may be needed find CPU and/or GPU temperatures higher than normal see Notebookcheck review for references . Padding mosfet VRMs is highly recomended because they tend run too hot. main thing is laptop produce less heat while still running reasonably. Undervolting tends help substantially. For gaming it is mostly advisable restrict CPU performance disable turbo or restrict package power or lock max multiplier so that GPU is more likely run unrestricted.

I have been using my XPS 13 9300 for almost 2 weeks now and complaints are always over-dramatic. There are no issues that I have noticed aside from some random stuff that almost every laptop has. really in-depth overview of things that someone might find annoying here is a list laptop get pretty loud doing anything graphics intensive but there is no whining sound it just sounds like smaller fans spinning really fast. get fairly hot your running anything graphics intensive after around 20 minutes. But remember this laptop is super thin and very light so it is be expected. are planning game on this frequently though I would not get any kind of ultrabook. your not planning on running graphics too much then this laptop remains pretty cool and dell has optimized this laptop have excellent battery life. I go about 8-10 hours without needing charge. Random Wi-Fi disconnects maybe once a day Screen Flashes something do auto-refresh I believe this is not a bad thing but it bothers some people Average quality speakers but definitely not bad they work just fine for most normal media consumption Software stuff implemented by Dell that I believe is related battery life. Dell Power Manager that's installed seems change speeds a little but tell this laptops power is being throttled a bit for sake of battery life. You install a fresh version of Windows that may fix this but I didn't and don't think it's necessary Other than that stuff this laptop while a bit pricey is definitely gorgeously designed and is pretty much exactly what I thought it was going be. is probably smallest 13 ultrabook but nice 16 10 aspect ratio and borderless display this laptop feel around a 14in while being crazy light and portable.

Hi 1. Open Device Manager type devmgmt.msc in Windows search box . 2. Expand Sound video game controllers and right click on Realtek High Definition Audio . 3. Select Update Driver Software . 4. Click on Browse my computer for driver software . 5. Click Let me pick from a list of drivers on my computer . 6. Put a check in box Show compatible hardware not already checked. 7. In list of devices click High Definition Audio native driver . 8. Click Next . 9. On Update Driver Warning box click Yes install driver . 10. Restart laptop prompted. not prompted then no restart. To get back Realtek driver do it again but reverse names in steps 1 and 6. SK

audio crackling seems be a perpetual problem Dell. 's result of a number of design decisions. These include - Killer chipset dodgy video drivers poor power management and poor thermals. Undercooling helps turning off turbo boot helps running on mains power helps changing audio drivers helps but... all fixes published only address one of contributing factors so things get better but not perfect. To be fair it's difficult replicate because it depends on network activity graphics activity ambient temperature charging/battery status and how good thermal pasting is but despite promises Dell haven't really tried that hard either or I'm sure they would have fixed it. Maybe there is a cost implication or problem needs affect more people? I finally gave up because audio is really important me sent my new XPS 15 back and bought a MacBook Pro. I still use my 3 year old Latitude for writing email browsing CAD and because I like Windows - but use Mac for anything that needs real-time low latency performance. In reality Linux/macOS is designed around real-time and Windows isn't.

Sounds like a botched explanation. Nvidia G-Sync is name of dynamic refresh rate feature. Nvidia PhysX is physics acceleration feature for video games. Nvidia Optimus is feature that switches between internal graphics card Intel GPU and external graphics card Nvidia GPU . They are trying say that G-Sync is dynamically setting refresh rate. part about PhysX is wrong. I have a Dell G5 5590 a 144hz display. does not have dynamic refresh rate G-Sync . I don't know there are possible configs G-Sync. My display always runs at 144hz.

Are sure your G5 5590 has a 144Hz display? There are models where screen is only 60Hz e.g. one i5-9300H on Dell's site . Yes explanation makes no sense. ChadValijean is right in that Nvidia PhysX has nothing do framerate but I also add that G-Sync or FreesSync does not limit your display's refresh rate in any way. dynamically syncs your monitor's refresh rate a game's FPS eliminate screen tearing. But when 're on your desktop or doing any other sort of tasks your screen should be running at 144Hz. Optimus technology also shouldn't have any impact on your display's refresh rate. That offloads work your iGPU your discrete GPU is not needed so your laptop extend its battery life. Both GPUs should support 144Hz. Edit Have gone into your Nvidia Control Panel check refresh rate there?

Are trying set refresh rate for built-in intel gpu which might not support 144hz? You might have check and set any nvidia-specific display parameters from an nvidia app not windows control panel or from app/game 're trying use.

Unplugging battery won't do much because cooling design and Dell's thermal management are inherently flawed. biggest culprit seems be uncooled Mosfet VRMs on top of both CPU and GPU. 's a well known issue among XPS 15 lines that none of paid reviews out there address about it. Undervolting won't help much throttling eventually occur under sustained load. Disabling turbo boost is not a proper solution that's like throwing your money out of window. Dell finally addresses this in new XPS 15 2020 by actually covering Mosfet VRMs under heat sink. Though only through stress test that we tell. I would say once thermal review for new XPS 15/17 comes out should ditch this piece of junk that is XPS 15 9560. We less people romanticizing XPS line on this world.

They're basically same computer. 2-in-1 was launched as 7390 before Dell decided change all their model numbers again.
2-in-1 has a soldered ssd. That's a big difference for me.

7390 2-in-1 came out at end of September and was first of XPS lineup updated build 16 10 display minimal bezels . They changed naming convention that model away from 9XXX numbers 7XXX numbers because they claimed they wanted all of their premium laptops start 7XXX numbers. Then when they launched new XPS 13 9300 they decided change numbers back old naming convention. To answer your question here are differences between 2-in-1 and 9300 7390 2-in-1 has soldered RAM and SSD presumably device thinner 9300 only has soldered RAM SSD is replaceable They both use same 10th-gen Ice Lake processors They both have 16 10 display ratios identical displays including touch They both have similar batteries and similar battery life FHD models have significantly better battery life than UHD displays 7390 2-in-1 has new vapor change cooling system that just looks like a plastic cover placed over heatsinks 9300 does not have new cooling system but reviews says that performance on it still better than 7390 2-in-1 in some benchmarks although it does run hotter. One review said that increased performance may be due updated system settings on 9300 since specs were otherwise same. I personally noticed that my 7390 2-in-1 was faster boot and more responsive after latest Intel UHD drivers and most recent BIOS 9300 has an updated keyboard more key travel than 7390 2-in-1 but they also got rid of separate pg up and pg down keys instead making left and right arrows larger and placing pg up and pg down keys as function activated keys. They both have same trackpad. Obvious but might as well point it out 7390 2-in-1's keyboard be folded back completely and be used as a tablet. ports are identical on both models while 9300 is slightly smaller almost imperceptibly thinner and weighs slightly less. Big difference 9300 has Windows Hello facial recognition support and a better webcam. 7390 2-in-1 has no Windows Hello facial recognition and a potato web cam. They both have fingerprint readers. I think everything else is same.

Hi Run a monitor diagnostics test and share a picture see issue could be seen in test. To run built-in diagnostics 1. Ensure that screen is clean no dust particles on surface of screen . 2. Unplug video cable s from back of computer or monitor. monitor then goes into self-test mode. 3. Press and hold Button 1 for 5 seconds. A gray screen appears. 4. Carefully inspect screen for abnormalities. 5. Press Button 1 on bottom of monitor again. color of screen changes red. 6. Inspect display for any abnormalities. 7. Repeat steps 5 and 6 inspect display in green blue black white and text screens KP

I just got 7390 2-in-1 and it has 16 10 and Ice Lake like 9300 and it's worth it. Not sure where are hearing slower there are maybe some certain benchmarks it's a few percent slower but 10x as many that trounce older one especially once graphics are involved. They are both same generation processor but Comet Lake is on older 14nm process it's more like 9th gen they never launched while Ice Lake is on new 10nm process and more efficient and double graphics power.

They improved alot of things newer model. base model now has a much brighter 500 nit screen as standard. old one hit 300 nits. newer one has a 100% srgb display. Older one hit around 65%. speakers have been improved. track pad is much bigger. processors are not slower. Ghz clock speed isn't only way measure perfomance. What also matter is instructions per clock or ipc which has improved alot on newer models. Graphics on i5 has also seen a bit of a bump i7 having biggest jump. older models also have big issues overheating yes they may be advertised as hitting 4ghz or more but in reality that's an up speed they hit it for a few seconds but actual sustained performance is far far lower.

new CPU in 9300 is... hmmm. In CPU performance it's slightly better than 4 core CPUs in older XPS models e.g i7-10510U . Long story short frequency is lower but they do more calculations in a single clock cycle Hz so it balances out. There are some use-case specific differences. For example Ice Lake 10th gen G parts are better for vectorized workloads. But 're dealing intensive multithreaded workloads then 6-core i7-10710U is usually better. For most people I would say... this isn't a big deal. But it is worth noting G4 and G7 configurations have much better integrated GPU performance 50% so this is a big plus for 9300 much better for any e.g light gaming . Anyway overall I would say 9300 is a better machine. I don't think it's worth extra money in an objective sense - improvements are nice but they aren't essential or game changing in any way. go Dell Factory Outlet and get an older XPS or a Latitude 7400 save hundreds of dollars and it'll do everything 'd for many years come. But subjectively speaking... 16 10 aspect ratio upgraded iGPU etc and comfortably afford 9300... well yeah... You do I guess.

Yeah that's how Optimus system works. When tab out check dGPU's usage on task manager game stops rendering in background so... there is not much works for dGPU do hence low usage. And when 're watching video it's considered be light task so system automatically use your iGPU do decoding instead of using your dGPU. frame rate drops 're describing is thermal throttling/power throttling and has nothing do GPU's usage. This is caused by CPU/GPU/any other components on motherboard overheating and laptop has intentionally gimp performance prevent itself from catching on fire lol. Fixing this ain't easy because cooling design thermal management are inherently flawed and not suit for gaming. You try undervolting repasting repadding padding Mosfet VRMs look it up alleviate issues.

I do my best answer your questions from my experience my XPS 9300 i7 / 16GB Ram / 512GB SSD / FHD non-touch. 1 - No my unit is completely stable. I have read a few people complaining of this issue on new models however it seems majority of people do not seem be experiencing this problem myself included . 2- IMO keyboard is fantastic. Having come from a Macbook this keyboard is a joy use. Only slight issue positioning of home / end / delete / arrow keys but its easy once get used it. are not sure get your self down an electronic store and try typing on one in person! 3- new models have windows hello so use Face ID log on - it works very well in my experience i have not had use fingerprint scanner or pin once. Having tested FP scanner it seems work well. 4- This is an interesting one. laptop wakes up pretty much instantly from sleep. HOWEVER my laptop is not used for a while 30min - 1hr then when i open lid dell logo appears for approx 10-15 seconds before i log in. I am not sure this is meant happen as a power saving option or my laptop is defective but it is slightly annoying. I am sure a bit of digging in power management settings this be fixed.... 5- For me I very rarely hear fan - only when i first got unit for a day or two whilst it was indexing and when installing software or updating system - then it is not super loud. I have heard that some people have fan on full throttle when watching a HD youtube videos however this is something i have not experienced. I do not use it for gaming or heavy CPU usage therefore i would not be able give a truly accurate answer. 6- Currently using info provided from a battery report my battery's average is 7.5 hours however others are getting around 8-10 mark. I am not sure as why mine is under performing - I only use it for surfing web and writing work documents....? This is something i look into. Other issues - i have been having problems my BT audio - audio stutters every 10-15 seconds. This is VERY annoying. I have tried re-installing audio driver but no fix. I suspect issue may lie MaxxAudio Pro Waves. - when on full volume keys vibrate at certain frequencies. This is slightly annoying also but i rarely have my laptop on full vol so i don't mind. Again i am not sure this is a design floor or my unit being defective. I have a technician due come out at end of this month investigate / fix both issues. Many of my posts on here fell on deaf ears so i made an effort try and help - I hope this helps

how I a complete backup of my PC so that I restore entire system I lose my laptop? Look up on restoring full system state for Acronis or another backup program . You'd have do it from a bootable external restore environment based on Linux or WinPE so that system drive is not in use . Mind this is mostly only applicable for restoring same laptop after disk failure or corruption or same laptop type while isn't useful for restoring on a different laptop - then 'd only restore data but reinstall programs and drivers. You might be interested in SSD cloning which is also supported by backup software but doesn't work incrementally like regular backup.
I use Macrium Reflect for this. Works flawlessly. I've recovered several times using this on my new machine.

Sounds like a funky OS. You'll attempt a Windows repair. Tap F11 as soon as your BIOS completes POST and keep tapping F11 slowly until Windows 10 Advanced Startup Options shows up. Then select Troubleshoot Advanced Options and run Startup Repair. are still receiving BSOD or other boot failure errors during boot after startup repair is complete go back into Advanced Startup Options doing same method as before except this time under Advanced Options select Command Prompt In Command Prompt type sfc /scannow and press Enter Once system file checker is complete attempt reboot. 're still having problems I would strongly recommend shipping system back for a fresh wipe and reinstall of Windows since it is only weeks old. 's better for factory do this as they have an image of your original hard drive and they pre-load all necessary drivers. I mean unless of course 're feeling adventurous. In which case go for it but don't say I didn't warn . Every driver has be installed in a specific order and run risk of deleting Dell Diagnostics partition reinstall Windows and end up formatting drive. this wasn't a new system I would say let's do it. But it's not. 's brand new. Just get them wipe and reinstall that boot drive and 'll be good go.

This sounds more like a software issue instead of a hardware issue. I would recommend backing up your laptop an external drive software like Acronis True Image and completely reinstall Win10. When reinstalling Win10 there's a few things should do. Beforehand go dell support website and download ALL drivers/software packages for your laptop and stick it on a USB drive or something. I'd recommend NOT connecting internet during installation process because a force create a microsoft account which don't your PC be attached and b it auto-install drivers that are likely be out of date compared ones got from Dell's website. So reinstall win10 install all drivers from USB. I also recommend using PC decrapifyer uninstall dell bloatware and please use Win10Debloater uninstall default Win10 bloat Office trial candy crush Minecraft netflix etc... This ensure cleanest installation of Win10 possible. After 're done I recommend imaging your hard drive again so restore that state later run into problems again. Ninja edit -- I add These were first steps I followed when I received my 7590 this past January. was plagued software issues sleep issues windows explorer 1909 bug bloat issues internet issues . Reinstalling Windows stable 1903 update fixed all of these for me. ALSO Look up how disable S1 Modern Sleep. 's a sleep mode designed for Surface tablets that for some reason Dell enables on their laptops causing weird sleep behavior and major battery drainage.

Your first step is ensure your system is configured properly. There are settings in BIOS and OS that prevents S3 sleep. FYI. There are only 2 sleep states S3 sleep S4 hibernate and S5 power off. S1/S2 refers different working states unrelated this issue. Navigate power option in control panel and go into advanced setting ensure everything is correct. Google it . I not repeat those available on Google. 1 your first step is ensure have a healthy sleep state. Set your sleep timer 1min boot clean then observe your system goes S3 sleep then wake it up. You do this a few times sure don't have a intermittent sleep problem. necessary use CMD run 'powercfg -requests' troubleshoot anything prevent S3. You unplug everything when do this - some USB/other devices may wake system up in wake-on-LAN or other similar events. 2 repeat step 1 power connected. This verifies your S3 is healthy when power is plugged. Note system has different setting when adapter is connected. 3 Leave system in S3 for 10-20mins observe any screen lit or temperature rise on keyboard hot spot is near F9 key which suggests OS secretly wake up due some events. have a Fluke meter thermal probe do this fairly easily. 4 have gone through 1 - 3 then are sure your OS is OK. Now get software part. Open browser Office and everything could think of. Then leave system idle trigger S3 and let it sit observe abnormal screen/thermal events. This normally happen in 10-20mins it happens. 5 system overheats in step 4 use binary search identify which software/element is causing this. This would take a few hours but it systematically find out what causes your problem.

Try disable dGPU from device manager. Alternatively switch S3 sleep mode instead of modern standby. From regedit go key HKEY LOCAL MACHINE SYSTEM CurrentControlSet Control Power modify or create not exists CsEnabled and set its value 0. Also happened have a samsung SSD use Samsung's NVMe controller driver or switch SSD mode RAID and use Intel's RST driver.
I solved that problem on my 9370 by reinstalling Windows from scratch and avoiding install any of Dells drivers or assistant software. Works for me.

Have same issue. Laptop would go sleep and not cool itself it was burning. Thermal protection would kick in and turn it off then. My solution was disable sleeping whilst plugged in so it would never forget cool itself down.
Try this 1. Start registry editor regedit.exe . 2. Move HKEY LOCAL MACHINE SYSTEM CurrentControlSet Control Power. 3. Double-click CsEnabled and set 0 then click OK. 4. Reboot

Most Dell machines come 10% factory wear which is actually intended bad calibration. Li-Po batteries degrade faster when charging 90-100% of their true capacity along trickle charging at 99-100%. Some companies feel bite on customer support. Knowing typical consumer not wisely avoid those limitations or program his charge schedule compensate for them they just ship 10% wear. Of course all claims of battery longevity in marketing material do not account for synthetic wear and reviewers get models without this most of times. There are ways manually remove 10% wear. Google it for your model. 1% off is either real wear or within margin of error of sensors.

incoming rant... My laptop i got in user tag years after I graduated bought laptop in 2019 graduated 2017 . That said I'd suggest looking elsewhere before considering a dell g7/g5. BIOS has been a CONSTANT issue for many people this laptop and pending on what version get determine how unhappy be. Issues include but not limited stuttering/freezing bad thermal performance fan curves lack of options for powefan profiles etc. Look into some other brands and see get opinions on how users feel that model like are here. As far as battery goes reasonably expect poor life just about any gaming laptop as far as I am aware. This line I'd say reasonably expect 2 maybe 3 hours mild use. Performance on battery be heavily reduced. With full tweaking expect enough performance watch 1080p 60 fps youtube but thats pushing it. DO decide get one heres what I did my laptop which is a slight upgrade and/or different from g5 mitigate most of issues and max performance thermal i redid my thermal paste for CPU/GPU screen color upgraded a 120hz panel storage replaced HDD 1TB SSD ram upgraded from 16 32GB bios stopped updating after 1.9 wish i could go back 1.3 i hear its best for my model power options tweaked settings so CPU doesn't throttle as bad on battery disable nvidia GPU in device manager for a more performance. surface temp i rigged a fan setup at my desk cool everything down just that bit extra. unless they fixed issues after my model made in 2018 doubt it expect similar fun times All said and done however for price I got mine 880 300 in upgrades it isn't a bad laptop that does great while plugged in and is adequate enough for short stints on battery. Desktop performance lets me run Destiny 2 1080p 60fps highest settings etc. TL DR look elsewhere before considering dell IMO. Linus Tech Tips constantly does laptop reviews. 're serious about using for classes I suggest getting a more battery friendly laptop not gaming

You ask a business for your preference of a free repair replacement or refund but are not always entitled one. For example consumer guarantees do not apply got what asked for but simply changed your mind found it cheaper somewhere else decided did not like purchase or had no use for it. When have a major problem a product have right ask for your choice of a replacement or refund. I'm in Victoria Australia and have had a similar experience twice I had take Dell VCAT. are complainant it only costs about 200 non-refundable get a hearing but it's a small price pay 've forked out 4k for a premium laptop which expect work for many years. Not unreasonable. We have one of best consumer laws in world. Under Australian Consumer Law all goods are expected last a reasonable amount of time. And that reasonable amount of time is SEVEN years. Period. Anyways as soon as a hearing date was set Dell immediately gave me a full refund. I'm assuming it would've cost them more than just refund they had defend themselves court costs 'strike' against their name etc. Most people don't take it this far and Dell know this so they get away it! But more people stood up these giants they would think twice about making products that don't last. We've all heard of planned obsolescence. Don't give up mate! Sooner or later they give your money back. Cheers hopefully I've been of help.

Some conflicting info on spec sheet for that one... Says Power through work day latest Intel i7 Quad Core™ processor option but then also only mentions Intel Core™ i3 i5 and i7 processors up i7-35x0M which wouldn't actually include any quad cores. I'm assuming that at some point a BIOS update added quad support so I'd definitely start there. EDIT Does BIOS identify all 4 cores?
Run CPU-Z and see what it says. I would install latest BIOS. That's a given should definitely do that.

Update I think I figured it out. When laptop is plugged in or docked ie on AC power it recognizes all cores and threads. Confirmed in dxdiag cpu-z and CB15 and CB20. 4 cores 8 threads when plugged in. On battery power it seems disable hyperthreading. Only 4 processes run and from what I tell it is using 4 cores just no HT. I could be wrong though our cups be disabling two cores on battery. Now I get muck about in battery settings see I disable that lovely /s feature.

I have same configuration as I tell what helped me reduce temps. Undervolting using ThrottleStop Turning off HyperThreading in BIOS Yes I know that by turning off HyperThreading reduce cores from 8 4 but this gives me much more higher and stable performance and reduced temps. As for undervolt it decreased my temps by about 5 degrees which is not much but was just enough stop it from thermal throttling GPU. Good luck!

I own this laptop exact specs have. 's true that this laptop heats up like crazy and has aggressive fan profiles. Another redditor and I both swapped out our thermal paste for liquid metal. Anyways try following things Basics - Make sure 're playing while laptop is charging 're probably doing this already . battery 't deliver enough power for a powerful GPU thus lowering performance. Windows settings - Right click battery icon in taskbar down below and click Windows Mobility Center . One of tiles shows an image of a battery and probably have balanced in that same tile. Click on balanced and set that High Performance . This increase maximum power delivered your laptop which means more performance but lower battery life. NVidia Control Panel - Right click desktop then NVidia Control Panel. In menu on left click Manage 3D Settings . In list of settings scroll down Power Management Mode . Set this Prefer maximum performance . This tells GPU that performance is more important than battery life. Now on that same page go Program Settings . Check Fortnite is in list of programs. this is not case click Add Browse and go wherever fortnite is installed possibly C Program Files Epic Games Fortnite . Add whatever starts Fortnite I expect this be Fortnite or Fortnite.exe . it is in list ignore that part. Set power management in this list also this is not on prefer maximum performance . - Make sure it uses High Performance NVidia Processor how however it's called and not Integrated Graphics or Auto Select . This forces game run on NVidia GPU. - In control panel click Adjust image settings preview in left menu. Select Use my performance emphasizing and set this performance. This reduce graphics a bit there's a preview so see effects directly for a bit of extra performance. G75 and that whole jet engine design series was so badass. Now all ASUS machines are these flimsy super thin ultrabook style machines that favor aesthetics over consistent internal cooling. They use these crappy AMD-in-tandem--GPU systems that share heat pipes between two and crappy buggy software regulate temps and voltages software that mind breaks half time under most normal of circumstances. All this results in temps that regularly climb into mid high 90s which for modern processing architectures is actually within spec but still hot enough for concern when failure threshold is just above 100 degrees Celsius. fear of having these software systems break and fail cool processors in time prevent damage is one of many reasons I hardly ever touch my GA502. All this could be avoided they just nut up and machines a little thicker better pasting dedicated heat pipes and bigger fans and jet engine series as I like call them is proof they do this and still have laptops looking quite nice and very portable. In fact I favor old aesthetic from a purely visual standpoint as well. I don't know what it is about gaming PC manufacturers feeling like everything has be as thin and light as possible. This is a tangent frankly this whole comment is but cell phone industry did this excessively until like three years ago when they realized they simply 't pack all these features into an ultra-slim ultra-light design without making concessions on battery and heat yes phones and tablets overheat and it happens more often than many think . Now 'll notice cell phones are getting bigger and heavier better displays tonplacate ignorant masses who thought slim-and-light was just bee's knees. big difference cell phones is that your battery gets too hot expands punctures itself on an internal component and ignites your handheld device just turned into a chemical bomb. On a laptop however thing just fail operate before anything gets hot enough physically harm user... But 'll still have lost some expensive hardware. 's not just an ASUS issue Dell has same fixation their Alienware M15/M17 series being super thin and while those do actually function better under most circumstances while hot 90 Celsius range they control throttling and still deliver consistent performance they shouldn't be getting that hot in first place. No matter what GPU choose that CPU all of them be bottlenecked. Most of games don't use CPU that much so in 99% of cases 'll see your CPU utilisation at 30% while GPU is at 99%. That doesn't mean won't get some good performance out of it. 's about that in terms of graphic intensive games CPU always wait for GPU no matter it's an 2080ti or a 1650ti it's only about what performance that graphics card push in end. To give an example CPU at 30% utilisation and 1650ti at 100% utilisation get 60FPS in a specific game While in same scenario but an 2080ti get 100fps at 100% GPU utilisation. heres steps. first try this 1. shut down pc turn power switch off on psu. wait 15 sec. 2. power on go bios F4 aura off 3. go into windows shut down again flip psu again. 4. power on bios aura on then see board re syncs aura app. steps above fail do this may take 1-2x but it does work 1. uninstall aura and lighting services. 2. go into program files asus erase anything that says aura or lighting service 3. go into program 86 erase asus and lighting service folders. 4. install cc cleaner and clean registry files or B manually delete aura and lighting service registrys in regedit. 5. shut down. wait 10 sec power on bios aura off. 6. install latest aura. shutdown wait 10 sec 7. power on bios aura on now when go into windows should see it blink and go all rainbow then have control again.

I have one in use for about 2 weeks and at first I was really disappointed. This device really has a problem temperatures when in stock conditions. At first battery run time was not near those values represented in youtube reviews but newest firmware 5 6 1/2 hours below mentioned office tasks are realistic which is pretty sweet in my opinion. Overall build quality is more than OK for price available ports are also decent and I like look because it looks not gamey . I ve bought mine for 1350 EUR 4800HS 1660TI 16GB RAM 1 TB NVME incl. Taxes compared G14 in same configuration rougly 2000 EUR incl. Taxes this notebook offers good value. Coming from a desktop I ve always found it somewhat strange that temperatures from 85 - 95 C are considered normal for a notebook. I personally accept temperatures around 80 C they occur under heavy performance duties aka gaming. Average CPU GPU Temperatures below tweaks Office tasks like browsing coding watching videos 41 - 54 C Gaming Bannerlord Total War Warhammer 2 65 - 72 C Unfortunately fans are not software controllable yet so when doing office tasks my temps slowly increase from 40 54 C and fans then start working. Software related Probably most f upped power plan settings I ve ever seen did result device deliver a minimum 100 % of power cpu - CPU temps when browsing avg. 65 - 67 C Can be solved by reducing minimum wattage 3 - 5 % device constantly boost cpu under heavy conditions like gaming it is not close necessary set maximum wattage 99 % this cause lower base clock speeds which is not what or modify one entry in registry so disabling CPU-boost in power plan settings. As this CPU is game changing powerful I did not notice any differences. Armoury Crate Performance Settings do some really strange things on my device so I ve set mode Windows and modified two power plan settings that I am comfortable Hardware related pasting is really poor I estimate Dies have been covered by about 95 % I have repasted every chip that is cooled by heatpipe one tube of 3.5g Gelid GC extreme - really solid improvement. Just be aware that different screws have been used so take notes or pictures. Even when unscrewed heatpipe does not come off easily apply some reasonable force. Before this process I ve only done some mods on desktops so this whole thing felt like a operation me D When correctly done this should not remove your warranty in most countries afaik air vents of CPU GPU fan are blocked by what I call it AMD paper. Removing this paper again decrease your temperatures by a lot. This void your warranty so do it as are comfortable it or not. ASUS states this is improve air flow other mainboard components see youtube reviews but I call that bullshit. exact same chassis has been used for a new Intel version of this notebook and guess what despite exact same components air intakes are not blocked. I did take a risk here because I feel this way notebook has a chance reach a respectable life span otherwise I think those temperatures it be case of warranty runs out and it destroys itself. There is a temperature sensor for NVME present and temperatures now are same or lower I did not any notes for this unfortunately.

I've run into this issue a bunch. In Bios go Boot CSM Launch CSM Enable. I would also disable Fast Boot which is in Boot Configuration. Edit that doesn't work let me know and I give some other steps try.

Hello Had same issue M2 nvme ssd on an another Asus Board. is your ssd NVME or SATA ? try this and read it end hope your bios is same and i know some of your options are already right Verify SATA controller is set - EnabledSet SATA Mode - RAID Go back one screen then select Onboard Device Configuration. Set SATA Mode Configuration - SATA Express Go back one screen. Click on Boot tab then scroll down page CSM. Click on it go next screen. Set Launch CSM - DisabledSet Boot Device Control - UEFI onlyBoot from Network devices be anything.Set Boot from Storage Devices - UEFI onlySet Boot from PCI-E PCI Expansion Devices - UEFI only Go back one screen. Click on Secure Boot go next screen. Set Secure Boot state - DisabledSet OS Type - Windows UEFI mode Go back one screen. Look for Boot Option Priorities - Boot Option 1. Click on down arrow in outlined box right and look for your flash drive. should be preceded by UEFI example UEFI Sandisk Cruzer . Select it so that it appears in this box.

I have same laptop. Armoury Crate profiles are kind of messed up in how they approach power. Manual is broken. just doesn't work so ignore it. Performance and Turbo deliver full power at all times latter ramping up fan speed a greater degree. Even I manually set minimum processor state 5% done through advanced power profile options in Windows control panel in either profile CPU never downclocks remaining in 4.0-4.2 GHz range. In Silent mode processor downclocks properly. There's a registry tweak for power options that exposes a separate option disable turbo boost all together so CPU's maximum frequency top out at 2.6 GHz. I did this for Silent profile and it's been working out really well. 's my primary gaming profile since most of games I'm playing are older and/or not particularly demanding. should work well for Oblivion in your case and it's also surprisingly capable for newer releases. With optimized silent profile system still average more than 90 fps in Forza Motorsport 7 a minimum of about 75. Instructions for applying registry fix are available in this thread Good luck.

That doesn't sound like any beep code that Asus uses here is list of what they use One short beep - VGA detected No keyboard detected Two short beeps - When using Crashfree recover BIOS new BIOS is successfully recognized. One continuous beep followed by two short beeps then a pause repeated - No memory detected One continuous beep followed by three short beeps - No VGA detected One continuous beep followed by four short beeps - Failure of Hardware component Hope this helps good luck! This try keep any personal files such as document music pictures but remove any application that was installed after date selected. Select Windows logo Bottom left of your screen - Select Settings gear wheel icon - Select Update and Security - Select Recovery .- Advanced Startup Click Restart Now - Select Troubleshoot - Select Advance Options - Select System Restore - Select a previous date from list Ensure that Show additional restore point checkbox bottom left is checked being shown - Select Next then Finish - Please wait for a response from Computer stating that System Restore has completed. I just got an A15 a couple days ago. I only use it connected my TV as an HTPC and for living room gaming so I 't comment much on its suitability as an everyday laptop. That said my impressions are I think design looks nice and build quality is pretty good. keys and trackpad feel good me. screen is kinda washed out but considering insane amount of CPU and GPU power 're getting at this price point it's hard complain. feels lightweight considering how big it is. lid for screen looks pretty classy and it opens surprisingly little effort. cooling solution is good. Temperatures stay low and nothing throttles. could be quieter but could say that about any gaming laptop probably. I've never owned a gaming laptop before but I've been reading a lot of reviews. Using it in Silent mode often allow it completely stop fan and then it's obviously completely silent although when it does occasionally spin up it's kind of annoying. minimum fan speed is 2200 RPM which is audible and it has kind of a whine it. Depending on what 're doing fan also sometimes speed up and slow down and that's noticeable. I don't have much experience Windows laptops so I don't know this amount of noise is common. I think bottom line is 're looking for a laptop that's thin lightweight classy super-quiet and has a super-great screen get a MacBook. You're going be pretty disappointed this laptop. But A15 is pretty inexpensive it has lots of RAM and fast storage it's upgradeable it has probably best mobile CPU money buy right now it has a strong GPU and it has a nice keyboard and trackpad. So there are pros and cons. I think A15 is definitely a great value for sure though.

M.2 slots are connected differently on motherboard. one between CPU and PCIe 16x is connected CPU directly and second M.2 slot is connected through Northbridge chip. got really high speed M.2 like 5000Mb/sec Sabrent drive might get better speed top M.2 slot than bottom M.2 slot. I 't find 100% verifiable and reliable source but it seems like some random testing I saw on Youtube reported about 5% speed difference between that 2 M.2 slots.

for those who read this in future it turns out - it doesnt matter since Corsair Force Series MP600 NVMe PCIe Gen4 x4 M.2 I bought for it have their own heat sinks and so dont fit unless remove heatsink that comes motherboard... this didnt occur me until i was installing them. heatsink that came mobo is now in trashcan. Sidenote - M.2s do not come screws or little posts - they assume your motherboard provides those which this ASUS board did so I was fine but had a moment of panic when opening Corsairs. In addition answer i found is a little more complicated than I thought - M.2 next CPU is listed and 1 but it is only PCIe 4.0 have a 3rd gen chip otherwise it is 3.0 - M.2 heatsink next northbridge chipset labeled 2 in manual is 4.0 regardless of your CPU. Hope this helps someone one day. thanks all who helped me!

I have this same laptop purchased for 1 300 when Best Buy had it as one of its daily deals a couple weeks ago. Out of box Armoury Crate software was saying one of its components needed an update. would download and install but update notification would still come back. wasn't really affecting anything so I left it alone. I tried undervolt using ThrottleStop but my settings were too aggressive causing an endless BSOD boot loop. Tried using built-in recovery partition but it got stuck in middle. I ended up wiping drive completely and starting over a bootable USB. After some initial trouble getting Armoury Crate and SSD cache set up properly it's been working fine - for most part. I love feel of keyboard hardware packs a punch and I achieve 4-5 hours of battery life in Silent mode doing basic tasks without an undervolt which is great for a laptop a high-power six-core CPU. Haven't done a ton of gaming yet but in Performance mode it has no problems maintaining a solid 144 fps in Doom 2016 at a mix of high and ultra settings. Temps seem stabilize in 70-75 range when fans ramp up which get a bit loud but this is a characteristic have expect from a thin and light gaming laptop. screen is amazing. You charge it via USB-C which be handy a bit of extra juice in a pinch. fact that it comes a 1 TB SSD out of box is nice and add more via a second M.2 slot. Note that standard 16 GB of RAM is soldered motherboard and runs only in single-channel mode. I would recommend ponying up another 60- 70 on a second 16 GB stick put in free available slot as 'll see a noticeable bump in CPU performance by moving dual channel. only thing about physical design that I really find negative is fact that WiFi card is also soldered motherboard. At least it's an Intel 9560 which is an excellent unit but moving up WiFi 6 later is out of question unless get an external dongle. Their decision do this on GU502GV is more baffling when consider that upgrade WiFi hardware in cheaper GA502DU which has a virtually identical form factor. Overall I'm satisfied it. At its current sale price of 1 450 as of this writing I think it's a bit overpriced but it comes back down 1 300 again I would say it's worth it.

I don't have a workaround but do have most likely reason for your having issues and a suggestion. ZEN 2 processors are rated 3200 MHz actually MT/s processors. Anything above that is dependent on your memory controller silicon lottery . Also using 16Gb DIMMs this also stress your memory controller more. I saw that your memory is on QVL list for board but board is not processor. That said are just using DOCP or are tweaking settings? Maybe try using Thaiphoon Burner and DRAM Calculator for Ryzen combination tweak your settings turn off DOCP and manually apply settings . Good luck!

Type and search Sound settings in Windows search bar 1 then click on Open c. Check speaker volume set mute mode . Click on Sound Control Panel in sound settings. d. Select Playback tab then select Internal speaker and click on Properties e. Select Levels tab use slider bar adjust volume level and check it does not set mute mode then click on OK save. Mute mode 2. Enable and reinstall driver in Device Manager a. Type and search Device Manager in Windows search bar then click on Open . b. Enable device option does not display that is meant touchscreen function is enabled already please continue next step c. Right-click on Internal Speaker then select Update driver . D. Click on Search automatically for updated driver software e. Windows is searching online for drivers. f. automatic update is completed please click on Close 9 . g. fail update speaker driver in device manager please go ASUS Support Site download and install Audio driver learn more about How search and download drivers following pictures are current version as a reference please download latest version from ASUS Support Site.
I would say probably 3200 MT/s RAM is what CPU is rated for but why do run a single DIMM? FYI 64Gb kit listed is 4 of same DIMMs as 16Gb single your asking about.

For one thing are best off buying a kit of 2 sticks of DDR so a 2x8GB kit 16GB as sticks are likely be better matched that way. Second thing is 32gb kits are less likely overclock well due them having dual rank chips. Third is that a 3200 rated kit have been tested at that speed on intel and is less likely run stable at that speed on AMD. So it run 3200 buy a 3400 kit. Also because of silicon lottery could get a kit that overclocks well or one that doesn't.

Hi Destroyer10super thanks for reaching out our team. We do apologize for any inconvenience and we'll be more than happy assist. Was this issue always present or did it recently develop? Also were there any software or hardware changes around time this issue started? We'd recommend that factory reset your device. However before doing that reset Be sure that your device has at least %50 charge life and Logout from your Google Account remove FRP Lock. Also just be advised your data be wiped. Any information that's not backed not be able retrieve. - Power off your device and wait a few seconds. - Press and hold Volume Up Power buttons together until recovery mode screen appears. These button combinations change on different modals. - When see Asus logo release Power button but keep holding Volume Up until recovery mode screen comes. - Leave all buttons when Recovery Mode screen appears. - Go Wipe Data/Factory Reset option using Volume Down and press Power button confirm it. - Go Yes –Delete All User Data using Volume Down and press Power button continue. - After process finishes go Reboot System Now and press Power button.

Switching disk interface AHCI from IDE or RAID changed way your computer interfaces your storage devices your operating system. Likely what happened was that Windows was still expecting your disks be connected IDE/RAID controller and tried communicate them but was failing. Somewhere along that chain of reboots it installed drivers for AHCI controller and was able boot again. To answer your question no it's unlikely that setting a BIOS password had anything do preventing Windows boot. Although I highly recommend against setting a BIOS password unless know what 're doing as it adds needless complication for barely any security gain whatsoever.

There's no reason that should be afraid brick your computer just because install another OS onto it. Linux runs well on most Thinkpads. There are other computer makes that are far less linux-friendly eg. Acer or HP but that one cannot generalise. Yet Thinkpads especially older models just go ahead.

My T440s works perfectly Linux one issue trackpad - see below . 's a very similar machine yours so I would imagine that should also be fine. one minor issue I had was that trackpad would sometimes not wake up correctly after laptop went sleep. But that might be reoslved now because I last tried it a year ago.

I wouldn't worry about bricking your computer simply by installing Linux. You're basically only writing data your hard drive this way and not much go wrong that. You could brick your computer by flashing a BIOS update and something going wrong for an example.

EVERY ThinkPad I've ever owned has run Linux nearly perfectly. I have Debian running on my x220 x230 P50 X201s x201 and soon W541. I just DD an image from one linux machine another. older ones Classic Keyboards and no dGPU tweaks but 't brick your laptop just by installing an OS. You it temporarily non-bootable but there's nothing do that would prevent reinstall of Windows or Linux. I recommend getting a USB drive or second SSD/HDD and boot a LiveOS version of something like Ubuntu Pop!OS or MX. There are plenty of HowTos guide . Good luck and welcome Team Tux!

As a fun weekend project I tried get as much of Windows 98 SE working on my ThinkPad T60 as I could. laptop officially only supports Windows XP and later and a lot of things like network access couldn't work. That said I did find a generic VGA driver capable of driving higher resolutions and colors and a USB 2.0 driver that let me transfer files off and on albeit unreliably . I was able install Office 97 and Photoshop 5.5 and get some real offline work done! Tried play games as well some like Midtown Madness 2 worked great others like NFS 2 SE and DOOM worked but in 256 color mode which is messed up in this generic driver. I wish there were a driver for ATi X1400 for Win9x but I wasn't able find any. Overall it was pretty fun one-time experience! As someone who grew up Windows XP it was fun going through DOS and ScanDisk and everything Wild West days of Win9x from before I was born. '

I made switch from a Surface Book my current X1C5 a few years ago. primary reason for switch was fact that I simply 't live Windows and Thinkpad's generally have great Linux support but sum it all up Thinkpad comes out on top as better laptop by far in my opinion. Surface Book is cool but unless really detachable tablet as a feature I don't see a sensible reason buy one. Thinkpad wins in following areas for me - Better keyboard - Trackpoint - More durable - More servicable - Linux support - Much better IO - Much faster SSDs - Better WiFi Intel - Native ethernet - Integrated WWAN I use it so much! - Matte display - Lighter smaller and hinge is far better. Stiff no wobble and rotate a full 180 degrees. x200B Surface Book has a few things going for it though especially use your computer for media consumption primarily. - 3 2 aspect ratio - Better speakers - Detachable tablet and great pen support - dGPU optional in base x200B only thing I miss about Surface Book was fact that design was so unique and tactile feeling of detaching screen awesome click sound is artificial was so satisfying. In end though Thinkpad is much more comfortable use as a pure laptop. I feel Lenovo has pretty much perfected conventional laptop at this point and I don't really understand why people go for XPS's and Macbooks that give 2 USB-C ports and a headphone jack and that's it.

Most not all SD card readers in thinkpads are PCI based not USB. As such not boot from them. You install linux on an SD card jus fine but it won't boot in thinkpad's SD card reader. You put that card in a USB card reader and boots fine as it it was a USB drive . You bootstrap i.e boot from your SSD so /efi partition etc all go onto your SSD plus drivers see sd card reader once kernel is loaded and then start SD card in reader. This requires a bit of work.
Get fastest card ... MicroSD cards be very slow. I have done this a fast USB3 flash drive and it was totally acceptable performance-wise.

I’m just gonna paste it here because i ’t find link anymore i had this text saved How To Install Ubuntu To A USB Drive Insert Ubuntu Live CD/DVD switch on computer and tell it boot from CD/DVD using your 'BIOS'. take a couple of minutes load and be presented two choices. 'Try Ubuntu' or 'Install Ubuntu' should select 'Install Ubuntu' You then be presented a number of options. You select bottom option 'Something Else'. This bring partitioning menu. Your Primary hard drive be listed as 'Sda' followed by any partitions that are on it like Sda1 or Sda2. Below this be your usb drive it be listed as 'Sdb'. Click on 'Sdb1' which is only partition on drive and select 'change'. You select 'use this partition as Ext4 File System' some distributions such as Mint reqiure manually select 'format' at this point . Then set 'mount point' as '/' which is root file system and click OK. You be taken back previous menu and that partition have a tick next it. Now click on 'Sdb' just above that partition this selects it as device install . Now just below is an option for where bootloader is be installed. is VERY IMPORTANT that CHANGE THIS OPTION. THE BOOTLOADER MUST BE INSTALLED TO YOUR DEVICE listed as '/dev/Sdb'. do not do this bootloader be installed your internal drive. You are now ready install your external device simply click 'Install'. You answer a few simple questions like 'name' and 'create password' then sit back and relax.

only macOS-compatible WiFi card that clear X230 whitelist is Atheros AR5B95 part number 20002357. This card is available on eBay here for 8.99. Placing IO80211Family.kext here in EFI/CLOVER/kexts/Other folder on your EFI partition assuming 're using Clover enable this card in macOS Mojave or Catalina. This card is WiFi only however stock Bluetooth daughtercard in X230 work fine in macOS. your X230 doesn't already have Bluetooth easily add this daughtercard in socket located under palmrest. You would part number 60Y3303 or 60Y3305. These are normally available on eBay for less than 10.

So I see some suggestions for AMD powered E L and T series. While these are great general purpose laptops I use my E495 for programming and playing older games on low settings I worry that it may not be quite specs are in market for. For one thing video editing likely benefit from a dedicated GPU and possibly a more powerful CPU though that may be less necessary . Finding a laptop like that for around 1000 is going involve some other compromises. may be worth looking at Notebookcheck's list of budget multimedia laptops for some good examples. For another AMD models aren't typically given best displays. A 250 nit 1080p display is just fine for me but may something better quality. Third E495 that I have is pretty upgradeable and serviceable storage ram battery but more and more models are getting soldered RAM treatement especially premium T-series . Thinkpad most directly targeted for multimedia content generation would be X1 Extreme. They have a more powerful CPU and a dedicated GPU nice displays and are quite serviceable. 's a little more pricey but I've seen first generation ones selling for around 1500USD here in states. I don't know how much that would end up being for across pond or find a seller a good warranty but I suggest check that model out.

I strongly suggest wait for AMD-powered L14 and L15. a new laptop ASAP maxxed out E495 and E595 should be within your price range E series are not as sturdily built hence my suggestion wait for L14 AMD and L15 AMD but they offer most performance for buck. Frankly speaking intended use for your new laptop is 50 tabs in a browser I strongly recommend switch Firefox video editing and video capture then I think almost any new ThinkPad except 11e series and maybe i3 models fare fine. Be prepared for suggestions strongly consider used T series laptops. However do intend buy a new ThinkPad specifically I'd recommend looking at L series - nowadays their quality got very close T series and they're cheaper.

1 I'm not sure sorry I don't own an X1G2 nor do I have an HDR display 2 3 When discrete GPU is enabled on a ThinkPad CPU doesn't enter lower C States . C States are modes in which CPU enters reduce power consumption and this really increase battery life and reduce temps. In my case CPU DGPU on idles at about 1 Watt of power whereas it disabled it idles at 0.5 Watts. This in my case reduces my battery life from 10 5 hours so be warned! I use an E490 a AMD GPU so while this might not be an issue Nvidia card have I did see C State issue reported X1 Carbon 6th gen which do use Nvidia cards. C State issue would also cause higher temps as putting more power in CPU would mean more heat is produced thus explaining higher temps. article below goes a little more in depth other battery saving measures try and compensate for having discrete graphics enabled I hope this helps!

Assuming are on Windows 10 1. Definitely re-paste first. As others have mentioned this is really easy do. Don't cheap out on thermal paste 2. You may use ThrottleStop undervolt your CPU. I've managed undervolt mine -155mV depends on quality of CPU die . You may catch several BSODs along way while fine-tuning your settings. Also pay attention SpeedShift values basically how aggressively your CPU go into Turbo Boost may wish limit Turbo Boost somewhat at least for one of profiles . All in all may get -10C or better limit aggressive of Turbo Boost . And/or... 3. ... sure that your BIOS is updated latest version and play around performance slider which is accessible by clicking battery indicator in Task Bar. I've noticed that for las 2-3 months noise and heat levels of my X1C6 are significantly bettelower than before when not using ThrottleStop. Lenovo definitely changed something in how CPU/cooling behaves. 4. Using TP fan application change your fan speeds is not ideal solution. Basically have as much performance as low heat output and fan noise as possible. But TP fan won't let achieve it. What it do is lower temperature by upping fan speeds which result in louder operation but lower temperature. Or vice versa - lower fan speed less noise but much hotter case temperatures.

I went from a 2011 MacBook Air an XPS 13 9360 an X230 an X270. I really liked XPS form factor but it didn't hold up well after 18 months. main issues were Awful coil whine. Poor thermals it gets quite hot fan runs often. Battery lost half its capacity and wasn't great begin since I got 4K screen. Adhesive on rubber rails on bottom failed and they came off. Soft touch material collects fingerprints / never looks clean. Stock wifi is awful on Linux and disconnects constantly. I replaced m.2 card but I believe they started soldering them motherboard on later models. it's same Broadcom WiFi and run Linux this is a dealkiller. form factor is really really nice but I won't be buying another one.

First a heatsink would be designed / held by hardware for specific numbers separation and pressure between semiconductor and heatsink. That must be known long before anyone answer your question. Second most all heat transfers in direct CPU heatsink contact when using thermal compound. Compound only fills microscopic air gaps them thermally conductive. Thermal compound be ten or twenty times less conductive higher thermal resistance than what transfers most all heat - direct contact. So why add thermal compound? Only because others ordered do so? To increase CPU temperatures. To increase thermal resistance. Ignore any answer that does not discuss how this stuff works and numbers. Why replace a thermal pad? They do not go bad become less thermally conductive 20 year later constant use. Third considering thermal paste then always ignore any recommendation that does not discuss relevant specification numbers. A first number that only informed mention is watts per kelvin-meter. Anyone who does not discuss that first specification number always read datasheets is best ignored. Then discover which highly touted and much more expensive brands are only similar or inferior.

I've had same problem as well but was able find a workaround for windows 10. Upon turning on your laptop 'll see a black screen which prompts hit ThinkVantage key interrupt normal startup. You'll then hit ThinkVantage key and then F1 get into BIOS Setup Utility. You then head config and then Alarm Beep. You'll see a option called Keyboard Beep. Disable that and then press F10 save and exit.

An issue I have my Dell XPS differences betweent i5 and i7 are not that big and usually barely noticeable. But since got this nice discount I would say go an i7 everything just a bit more future proof. But I would stay away from models v pro . That is a feature that only few people . difference between generations is also only a small improvement from one next but a 10th gen chip have better performance and battery life in comparison a 8th or 9th gen chip. One thing look out for in 10th gen chips is integrated graphics. chips that have a G1 or G7 G7 being better than G1 in their name have vastly improved graphics performance in comparison chips that have a U at their end. While cache is not as important as it used be general rule of thumb is more better. In general it is better have 2 sticks of 8GB for 16GB in total because then memory run in a dual channel mode. Giving better performance. x200B As for any recommendations Because a good screen and speakers I would suggest an X1 Extreme or a P1. These are fairly powerful machines 9th gen chips and have nvidia graphics chips for good performance or light gaming. But these are also fairly light and portable an okay battery life. On cheaper side a T15 is also a really good option. have maximum lightness and protability and don't a ton of graphics performance I recommend X1 Carbon. x200B I hope I was able give some insight! This is more for linuxquestions but should install whatever distro are going because there isn't anything bootable on drive after partitioning.

This may happen your boot flag wasn't set during partitioning. This should happen automagicly when let install set everything for yet sometimes it doesn't. So boot back into your live distro once up open gparted or whatever partioning utility it comes . Look for manage flags there should be check boxes next bootable partitions i.e. /boot/efi. check that box exit and reboot. Should work not your going have re-install it still doesn't work have other issues. Advise visiting that distro's forums for further assistance. HTH Regards --mac
