I’ve been wanting get an old ThinkPad for a while and came across an out of business company auction lots of ThinkPads. Initially I wanted an X220 but prices went above what I was prepared spend. Instead I went for a X240 and won one of lots. listing was a bit of a mess description and pictures not matching so in week between auction ended and pickup I was very excited find out I had made a good deal or just wasted my money. In meantime while surfing local classifieds for spareparts etc. as one do I came across a very reasonably priced X201 that I couldn't resist. 4 GB ram i5 processor battery seems decent and very little wear outside. keyboard is great and I love look of no trackpad. day came that I could pick up X240 and my suspicion towards listing turned out be justified. First of all HDD was 250 GB instead of 320 GB. No big deal 's getting swapped an SSD anyway. Instead of pictured 3-cell battery it came a 6-cell battery. Great! Unfortunately battery was DOA giving replace due normal wear warning in Windows and only maintaining a voltage of about 5v. internal battery appears be in decent condition and cosmetically laptop is fine. All in all a fun experience would probably be more critical towards listing another time. Next up both are getting new SSDs and I also have a new original battery in mail for X240. I plan on running a light linux distro possibly Lubuntu on X201 and dualboot Windows and maybe Fedora on X240. Both are also going get a thorough cleaning and get their CPUs repasted. In future I might upgrade RAM on X201 X240 is already maxed out at 8 GB. Ideally I would like get a new battery for X201 but I don't feel like entering 3rd party battery lottery and an original battery would cost me several times price I paid for laptop. Down road I might look into upgrading display and trackpad on X240 but for one I'm just going enjoy spending some time fixing up these fine machines. Honourable mention of my T490s from work in background which lured me down this rabbit hole.

compatibility of fans and heatsinks between different laptop models is very very low because in most cases these are custom parts designed fit a particular model and its variants. 's not impossible shoehorn a different fan into a laptop I've done this myself but that usually requires that already have parts on hand. 're only comparing pics of fans and heatsinks online then chance of success is much much lower.

Fans move air moving air sound. There are some tweaks that one fan more quiet than others but when staying within same physical dimensions and performance amount of air moved differences in noise be small any. Now your current fan is broken mechanical like rattling and scraping sounds then replacing it a fresh one at least remove those sounds giving an overall better experience. Also some brands just a shittier product than others resulting in more of these noises being produced on side on a new sample google about different brands and how users generally experience sounds they produce. Finding a 'compatible' fan for a laptop be very tricky there's so little space in modern machines that they pretty much tailored components.

There are two companies that special pliers for removing small screws. 1. Vampliers 2. Engineer Haven't used either myself perhaps some OP's chime in their results. I have considered purchasing a pair myself b/c its not a matter of but when . HTH Regards --mac

You probably used a screw bit that is one size too big or small. metal used in most laptop screws are pretty mild and malleable. Stick black insulation tape on it and try screw it out again. that doesn't work apply a small dab of metal epoxy cover up hole essentially it flush screw surface . Stick a screw bit in straighten it and let epoxy fully cure. should be easy unscrew it after that. Either way still buy a new screw install your M2 SSD back.
That looks like a job for locking pliers! Might also heat that screw up a little bit first they were too generous locktite could very well rip everything apart force pliers apply.

Of course L series laptop would be cheaper than X series one. L series at this point is basically budget T/X series - somewhat less durable than T/X series but still better than E series in this regard. I recommend X390Y 10th gen Intel processors. L13Y doesn't have any advantages over X390Y - it doesn't have Thunderbolt it doesn't have a keyboard lock and is built out of GFRP instead of carbon fiber. L13Y's predecessor L390Y had two RAM slots but L13Y lost them both in favor of a possibility of being configured smartcards - which is good 're an enterprise client who deals valuable data on their laptops but sucks 're not.

thinkpad rj45 adapter is a direct pin pin adapter for Ethernet. retains internal mac address for networking. This is useful for a corporate environment many devices all having set ip and Mac addresses so that admins use mac address access control. Using a thunderbolt adapter is different because instead of matching Mac address of computer Mac address correspond adapter used. This is useful for consumers but would Mac address access control impossible for corporate environments. Basically all of people hating on Lenovo for making a proprietary Ethernet port and adapter on their business laptops miss point that these are for business first and not necessarily for consumer. Consumers portability and compatibility business needs industry standard features such as a hardware mac address afforded by this proprietary port and adapter.

Thinkpad dongle is a breakout cable - aka controller is in computer it is basically a dumb cable. Thunderbolt is a whole adapter controller and everything rolled into one and work any thunderbolt computer.

Is it physically not possible because of missing 2 lanes? Screens are not driven by PCIe so should not be affected by number of lanes. You drive a screen use no PCIe at all on docks without Thunderbolt. For screens DisplayPort MST is used. Please post output of this command see an MST hub is detected xrandr -q show DP1-1 DP1-2 etc. for different ports of docking station connected port DP1 on my X1C5 DP1 is left port and DP2 right port. Short answer no. More details ThinkPad OneLink Dock is not a USB dock like other models that came after. still a pure dock in its philosophy and cabling/wiring. On that dock only USB ports and soundcard goes USB BUS linked 2 separate USB BUS . But Gigabit Ethernet DVI connector DP connector or HDMI connector and power button go directly motherboard and its chipsets. two laptops couldn't be more different. T470p notice p at end is a workstation meant for sustained workloads rendering etc . X280 is an ultra portable smaller screen and emphasis on battery life and non-sustained loads. Things in common 1. Both have 4 core CPUs 2. Both run linux fine only fingerprint sensors are not supported That's it. What is different 1. T470p has a proper 35W CPU 4c 8threads that run at full speed for a long time at a huge expense battery life so expected work mostly plugged in or on dock . 2. x280 has a 15W CPU 4c 8threads that car run at full speed briefly and then settles lower clocks avoid overheating. is still plenty fast for common use. 3. T470p has a 14 in screen x280 only 12 inch. 've never used a 12 inch before expect everything be small. Or large expect have very little real estate open more than one window at a time. x280 has 1360x768 screen just walk away or be prepared upgrade not trivial . T470p comes a base FHD screen. 4. T470p has a 2.5 in bay for it's main drive. This be a 2.5 SATA SSD or a 2.5 HDD or an adapter a 2280 NVMe SSD limited 2x PCI lanes. one buy has either for former two also buy an adapter upgrade NVMe. 5. x280 only has a 2280 drive either SATA base model or NVMe SSD. 6. RAM on T470p is fully upgradable 2 slots. 7. X280 has soldered RAM what buy is what 're stuck . 8. X280 has a USB-C Thunderbolt 3 port. T470p has none. 9. T470p has a removable battery. small one lasts about 2.5 hours bigger one about 6hours. X280's battery is not removable and lastas around 8 hours for same use light browsing . 10. T470p has probably discrete GPU. Works fine in linux. X280 only has iGPU. Do dGPU not unless plan on doing some 3D or other compute tasks or light gaming but plan on gaming don't buy a thinkpad . So see what kind of use case 've got and decision should be as clear as huge differences between two laptops. As for battery going bad keep charger on answer is most probably . You replace battery of X280 it's a tiny bit more involving. But minimise effects of constant charging by setting thresholds. I hope this helps. P.S. IF 're buying used sure there are no BIos passwords as they are unknown there is no way reset them.

Let's see... Then I found out that sometimes because of course only sometimes internal HDD caddy doesn't get seen and I have reboot it often twice before it sees it again. Well there's no caddy for internal disk - only a bracket. Disk itself is connected directly motherboard. This issue be triggered by either motherboard or disk most likely overheating . I had a problem T430 in past that disk was malfunctioning and as result it was not detected by system. After cleaning device and replacing thermal paste issue was no longer present. In your case your disk may be culprit. Oh and when install it into Ultra Dock there's a horrible coil whine. This looks like a disk or caddy problem. I have been using second disk adapter official one for years and I never had such an issue. Oh and play games newer than 2005 then it throttle GPU heavily after approx 30 sec of playing and get 10FPS. Have changed thermal paste and cleaned cooling assembly? Want replace WiFi chip? Can't! Because it's whitelisted! There was also a whitelist on your T530. Are all modern laptops incompetent? Aren't there any true workstation ThinkPads that DON'T throttle? I don't a thin laptop I a FUNCTIONING laptop! There are devices which do not throttle - such as this one check graph in Processor section . 's not a workstation but still... Majority of devices are not designed sustain prolonged boost clocks and after few seconds CPU reduces working frequency. In past vendors tried keep maximum boost clocks while now they are trying keep base clocks. Personally I also have same issue right now. I am looking change my T540p something newer but it is more likely not be a ThinkPad. I have observed that Quadro cards installed in workstations have a tendency fail after about three years. Current ThinkPads have only soldered GPUs so they die and 're out of warranty then buy a new device. You may ask what are choices then? Actually there are three Get longest possible warranty your device and try guess would more powerful GPU in future as cannot change it later. Buy a device Thunderbolt 3 port and no dGPU. For gaming buy an eGPU enclosure and desktop grade GPU later. This solution looks nice on paper but life is not so easy... Buy a device replaceable dGPU. last option requires a bit more comment. There are mobile workstations replaceable dGPUs - Dell and HP have them in their current porfolio. In past Lenovo had some of them too but they started solder everything starting from 2018 generation - last one replaceable GPU was P71. Personally I'm looking for either Dell Precision 7530 or 7540 as they are only 15.6 devices replaceable GPUs. Other options - Dell Precision 7730 7740 and HP ZBook 17 G5 and G6 are 17.3 . 7530 and 7540 have some issues/limitations thought Only 2x TB3 and 2x USB-A ports. 2.5 SATA port is available only as an option - order device HDD disk as otherwise won't get it. dGPU uses proprietary connector so cannot upgrade it outside Dell. You still install 7540's dGPUs in 7530 but it requires additional steps get drivers work. There's a lot of odd configurations on market poorest screen no camera or no antennas for LTE module so it's hard find a decent one. Dell warranty is calculated from production date not bought date. There is no problem find not used devices half of original warranty time. I'm still waiting my decision as Lenovo plans release T15p which seems be a successor of T540p which I am currently using . Depending on what they show I my final decision.

Just let linux installation take care of everything. On part where it normally tells where install linux it actually detect windows OS and ask what do. Just select Install Linux Alongside Windows and click next. next screen ask how much partition for linux.

My experience installing linux OS's ALWAYS format drive install on BEFORE installation. So prepare a live OS iso of linux of your choice on a USB stick put it in computer then start computer. When access BIOS do so change boot order so that USB stick is first. Hit F10 save and reboot. Boot live OS and use GParted included in most distros format drive install on. That wipes Windows off it. Proceed install your linux OS.

X240s and newer are fine especially portability - people just like hating on new things and this set of laptops was a different chassis from X230 and its predecessors which people liked a lot . didn't help that X240 which kicked off its series was missing physical trackpad buttons and maxed at 8GB RAM both of which were changed in X250 and newer . Since your budget is fairly low it's a good idea go for used/refurb laptops - something like an X200-series ThinkPad or an 820-series Elitebook or a E5200/E7200-series Latitude. All of these are business-style laptops which have an abundance of parts like projects right? and should be easy work on. These are all also 12.5 laptops though could go for 830 Elitebooks or E5300/E7300 Latitudes something bigger. I also mention that since were satisfied your i7-7500U I would say any i5 or i7 between around 2013-2017 should be fine for as well - this means anything from Intel's 4000 7000 series. There isn't a huge difference between these since they're all just 2 core 4 thread CPUs more and more efficiency could go older than this but starting from X240 do get a fairly big improvement in battery life partly from efficiency increase. Also every new generation came a better integrated GPU which may improve day--day performance a little so I wouldn't go too far from 7000 series. That being said pretty much any i5 or i7 is guaranteed be a marked performance increase from your Core 2 Duo and between 2011-2017 there were no significant improvements in CPU tech - it's only until Intel 8th gen came out when they were actually better i5s and i7s became 4 cores . really a zippy laptop put in a good SSD clean install Windows and don't run startup programs don't . SSDs are extremely underrated in performance - they get your boot times down 20s on a bad computer and 8s on a good one and just day--day usage a lot better for less than what a better CPU would cost. Keep in mind that in a lot of these old ish business laptops RAM and SSDs are really fucking easy upgrade so try not worry about those too much. Also get 1080p screen. At 12.5 a higher resolution give nothing but I have 768p screen on my X240 and it sucks.

Thinkpads have a Windows licence embedded in their BIOS so no buy one. Download Win 10 directly from Microsoft website and install it During installation process once connected network WIFI or LAN it check embedded licence verify it and attach a digital licence motherboard ID so no more licence requested for any further installation of Win10 do on this laptop . Just in case Windows installation ask for licence number preemptively read/get embedded licence number from a Linux Live CD/USB like Ubuntu live try by typing this command in a terminal sudo cat /sys/firmware/acpi/tables/MSDM But usually Windows 10 installation read licence directly from bios on Thinkpads models xx40 in 2014 and after. source Note I've installed no later than this week Windows 10 on a Thinkpad Yoga S1 for a family member this Thinkpad embed a Win8.1Pro license which is automatically recognized and validated by Win10 installation process .

Personally I would go full hd display. image quality is far far better. As already mentioned get a free win 10 upgrade from win 7. Plenty of tutorials arround web. disk is not an immediate concern and an easy upgrade in a couple years down road.

I have original bluetooth version one of that keyboard and also a Realforce 88u TKL same topre switches which are used in HHKB. I love both. Thinkpad keyboard is small and very light so it is great for portability. But I far prefer typing experience on a topre switched keyboard. Although some peopl ejust see them as an expensive rubber dome switch typing experience is so smooth and precise and 'thok' sound is die for . So when at home I use topre. However HHKB has an unusual layout. isn't a normal format and isn't a TKL. Personally I think I would hate that layout. 's too heavy be really portable and too compromised in layout match productivity of a traditional layout. You might consider Realforce R2 newer version than mine which has same submlime switches but in a regular TKL layout.

Lenovo X1 Extreme thermal throttling solution Undervolt i7 8750H and OC Scan Nvidia 1050ti I took up an X1 Extreme for weeks of testing and configuring. There are two adjustments which this ultra-book significantly faster and cooler. I do not recommend repasting its just nonsensical. There are only two basic changes made significant temp decrease and benchmark increase. Note X1 Extreme's Core i7-8750H is benchmarking in top 89% of ALL processors. Which means this X1 Extreme I configured runs faster than nearly 90% of all DELL MAC ETC other systems/configurations this same processor. Here are result steps below. Cinebench R15 score 1178 up from 966 . Lenovo 20MF000BUS - UserBenchmarks Game 39% Desk 108% Work 79% Full Result Intel Core i7-8750H Nvidia GTX 1050-Ti Mobile Max-Q SSD WDC PC SN720 SDAQNTW-512G-1001 512GB RAM Samsung M471A2K43CB1-CTD 1x16GB Quick context - i7 8750H is incredibly powerful. To access full power of SIX cores system must stay cool. Lenovo's cooling system outperforms Dell and HP in testing and significantly outperforms Mac Book Pro. So its already just about as fast as get in a light thin laptop- but its going get hot when running all that power. steps below help keep your processor running at full potential - its a safe and sound no chance of harm. two-step process must be performed in this order Start by turning off Lenovo intelligent cooling and set button performance. Also set your power mode Best Performance. 1 OPEN MSI Afterburner and RUN OC SCAN This is new tech on latest GPUs. This automatically run and adjust clock speeds while also undervolting your Nvidia GPU its max stable state. This greatly reduce GPU temps and improve framerates. also allow your CPU run faster when both GPU and CPU are under load gaming etc because it not be drawing as much power away and generate less heat - leading NO thermal throttling. Your system is smart it protects itself. NOTE This automatic process not change memory speed slider do that manually after. Slide it up 450Mhz for safe and sound performance. Save this profile and lets move on. 2 OPEN Intel XTU safely and securely undervolt. A child could do this. First please forget or ignore all bloat may have read posted by extreme tuners which overcomplicate. Forget about throttlestop. Some people are trying change their processor too much - trust me uber science nerds at Intel thought of all this already millions in research and development. I doubt balance needs of your processor better... ONLY reason we improve performance here is because we know one thing that Intel did not know when they made processor. Intel does not know what laptop their processor is going end up in. has work in a Mac Book or a Dell etc. different specs and cooling. We do know that this processor is incredibly consistent. Meaning they nearly all undervolt same way. Totally safe Intel's official XTU app gives only settings adjust your i7 your unique system. Configure your X1 Extreme as follows Open XTU app and simply slide slider labeled Core Voltage Offset down -0.150 V You are done. like add additional performance safely by also moving turbo boost power max up 75.000W for both short and max. Your X1 not allow add too much power. Sliding this up is removing any software handicap - processor still limit power per intel specs. Your X1 like your car is monitoring itself and has hard limits which not be changed by a slider bar duh. Make sure apply changes close and restart. Open app on restart and confirm values are set. Expect see large gains in frames games benchmarks and everyday processing. Anything beyond this is splitting hairs. Would like conclude a final word on this system. In my research I have seen post complaining about X1 temp and thermal throttling etc. Some folks report that they retuned system.. imagine frustration only find that ALL ultra-books get hot under load. To be clear - do not change anything about this machine - it is a beast out of box and temps are outstanding for an ultra book. Its never hot unless gaming and when under load really not do better without defying laws of physics. I sometimes wonder commenters understand that actual electric is running through system and a lot of it. Touch a 15W light after an hour. Here we have 45 W in a chip size of your thumb. Fire. Hot. Mac Book Pro prefer slow and cool - Lastly kindly note that watch HD movies in bed then buy an iPad. This is professional machine serious power - outperforms pretty much any other laptop on market and most desktops. All best!

There's definitely a lot more room for improvement throttlestop. Sure XTU may be simple but throttlestop give better results know what undervolt. You undervolt your CPU cache and Intel GPU at least -100mV.

Your comment on Intel doesn't know what laptop their processor is going end up in isn't reason undervolt CPUs. CPU Dies are manufactured in large quantities and have varying performance. For example Ryzen 1700x and 1700 are exactly same circuit and come from same batch. Some of 1700 chips could reach a higher clockspeeds than others in testing and they get branded 1700xs and ones that cannot get branded 1700s. reason we undervolt 8750h is because Intel has provide enough power for lowest denominator in a batch work at a set frequency. This gives a large room for tuning didn't get unlucky in silicone lottery

gains are substantial. CPU is able run at higher frequencies while Gpu under load and GPU is able maintain max frequency without throttling down. Plus get a GPU overlock. Under full load GPU temps hit only 60-61c - down from 76-80c. In terms of a real life example - I found low frames using Just Cause 4 at low settings during test and also universe sandbox slowing down simulation substantially after short time. As expected checked monitors and thermal throttling was clocking everything down. Controlling heat in an X1 means addressing two major sources. After GPU AND CPU undervolt I report 60 frames in Just Cause at High settings and Universe sandbox is able fully tax all 6 cores at 3.9ghz for hours of duration without simulation slowing down at all. So I would say both on paper and real world these changes together are substantial.

I have a T470 as my daily driver upgraded from a mid-2012 macbook pro. 's about 10% faster in terms of CPU graphics are a lot better I play SC2 on medium settings at 45fps instead of low at 10fps. I don't do too many intensive things other than compile code which is a bit slow. I would not recommend going for anything less than a T470. I turned off intelligent cooling option which seemed speed things up a little at expense of having fans on more often. I got mine 16GB of ram an SSD and a high dpi display video editing uses a lot of ram so I would recommend getting a ram upgrade and using an SSD your budget handle it. I'm using free calibration display settings from notebookcheck and it removed blue cast I was getting and it looks much more correct . This might be important when video editing as colors are important. However srgb production in general is pretty poor so 'd be better off doing it on an external monitor colors are especially important. I never used a T460 so I 't comment on it unfortunately.

I have a T460 my wife has a T470. I think there won't be any difference in speed are only considering cheapest t470 configurations an i5 CPU. They'll probably have same CPU 6300u . However T470 has USB-c so I would go t470 have a more future proof laptop. Regarding keyboards keys on T460 have a longer travel distance. T460's keys almost feel like a desktop whereas one on T470 is a very good and comfortable laptop keyboard. I think both are beautiful it comes down what one prefers. I feel like I am faster on T470 probably because key travel distance. I add one personal experience regarding keyboard of T460. I write a lot each day alternating between T460 and different desktop keyboards MS Sculpt Ergonomic Sculpt Comfort and Sculpt Mobile . I think typing on T460's keys is most enjoyable great feeling and key click sound . However keys are harder and I get tired faster on T460's keyboard. But that might be only me. So despite my enjoyment of T460's keyboard I would choose T470 I had pick between two today.

X230's had two screens both were 1366x768. difference was type of panel TN for terrible viewing angles/contrast/color and IPS for basically exact opposite. As for T480 stock screen is lackluster in terms of its coverage of srgb colorspace making it look lifeless. A replacement screen is easy drop in and there are many choices. find them low power IPS displays used in T490 X1C 6/7 series are drop in replacements provided they have four mounting tabs needed secure display lid two on top two on bottom . Here are your paths consider best color but a severe hit battery life theres some very nice 4k screens out there. better res great color and brightness 1440p hdr screens are nice. what I have my T480 went from 10 8hr max typical iirc. conserve battery and get best colocontrast ratio possible a low power screen like B140han05.7 would be best choice imo. Screen Suggestions 4k - BOE NV140QUM-N53 16.7m colors 1500 1 contrast ratio 500 nits brightness not sure on install 1440p - JDI LPM140M420 what I have in my T480 and X1Y3 or AUO B140QAN2.0 16.7m colors 1500 1 contrast ratio 500 nits brightness. JDI Requires WQHD cable brackets and WQHD lid fit. Swapped all these over works great needed some spacers keep this slightly smaller screen in place. Good double sided tape would likely have worked as well. Not sure about AUO screen. 1080p - B140HAN05.7 16.7m colors 1700 1 contrast ratio 400 nits brightness in my X1C7 confirm nice display Great display cannot confirm versions are available mounting tabs or not. Alternative option B140HAN01.2 or B140HAN 01.3 16.7m colors 800 1 contrast ratio 300 nits brightness. A truly drop in replacement no modding required has mounting tabs better than N140HCE everyone seems reccomend as it has a more shades of color think larger crayon box vs smaller Where get them? Ebay just sure have an explicit understanding from seller that are getting that exact screen. Return policies are nice as well. Encompass Authorized lenovo parts store needed likely for lid/brackets/cable. Might be able source these on ebay but voldermort likely have hurt supply lines for this. Expect slow shipping for most of these as they seem come factory direct from china. my parts took about 30 days US incl customs .

X2xx series are small and light not too bad work on either in my opinion. For example I have an X240 which I fitted -240GB SSD -Backlit keyboard -X250 Trackpad -8GB RAM -FHD 1920x1080 IPS panel All of those parts were under 40/ 40/ €40 and all add up a big difference. I then happened across an X260 i5-6300 motherboard and fitted that and it runs much cooler and efficient. I have tried a few Debian/Ubuntu distros and they all run great. Pop! OS seems have best battery life for me System76 Power Extension probably because its developed their own range of laptops in mind Overall I would recommend newest/powerful model CPU combo afford while leaving enough money for upgrades. use standard slim 68 24Wh battery then they weigh under three pounds! only thing I would warn against is keyboards are a little small and I see why people feel they are too cramped but its my daily driver now and i am always getting 6-7 hours out of mine stock batteries they have option of an internal battery for hot-swapping external ones and I usually have a second battery in my bag as well. Latitudes and Elitebooks should also be considered. Which is best comes down personal preference I find that HPs have more vibrant displays Thinkpads have excellent color accuracy and decent keyboards for a laptop and Latitudes are well balanced. issue I have right now is that there are so many options for Thinkpads that I feel kind of lost. T460s. needs have a good enough battery last me through day and it also needs be sturdy enough handle my daily abuse I tend handle my laptops quite roughly T460s. Although may be coming home both batteries at 5% battery life is Good not Great . I plan on using this for many years come and so having it be future proof is a must. Future proofing is a myth. By time have latest CPU 've already been outpaced by another one. Buy used machines every three years 'll be a lot happier. I enjoy being able rip things apart and tinker them mostly cause I tend break them a lot and so it'd be nice that's possible as well. Good news Thinkpads be taken apart. Business IT wouldn't have it any other way. Bad news modding eh not most brilliant idea. 's usually better leave things stock and just buy something newer or better equipped out of box or at most swap display A for display B which was also available on your model year. Keyboard/Trackpad mods aren't a terrible idea not great but not terrible but anything more extreme is a no-no-no-no. Since I plan on carrying this around me daily a lighter option would be nice. Gets DDR4 RAM and NVMe on all four PCIe lanes. X260/270 Good like 12.5 displays and are alright having your NVMe drives limited 2 lanes. From 300-450 T470s Better battery than T460s thanks more efficient CPU. Said CPU isn't a major upgrade in any other regard. A485 Good a bit of graphics horsepower on go for your Minecraft addiction. No PCIe 3.0 x4 for NVMe. From 450-600 T480 Intel version of A485. Note don't get four lanes on NVMe but get a power efficient quad core making around 30% more power than A485 and 200% power of T460s. T480s Same CPUs as T480 but get NVMe x4 lanes. WHERE DO YOU BUY? eBay keep an eye out for IT departments tossing machines.

This is what I generally call A REALLY BAD IDEA . x200B Why? Why do do this over just buying a P52 an 8750H already inside? What justifies jerry-rigging involved and a likely unstable laptop at end of it all? This makes no sense I cannot fathom a single reason do this. Coffee Lake CPU into a Skylake Motherboard Z370 Z170.. etc That's an enthusiast-grade motherboard not a custom designed one designed around power limitations and space constraints of laptops as well as only being on one CPU architecture Skylake. While it's true Skylake and Coffee Lake are fairly similar it's unreasonable assume they use same microcode. They don't. At all. What I am interested in and wondering about is someone like klem would be able update BIOS UEFI microcode accommodate for additional CPU. 1. Unlikely. 2. it were possible 'd be left an unstable laptop. P-Series is designed for stability from factory this would undo all of that. microcode that would be in your BIOS wouldn't be intended for hardware have leading BSODs and other issues. 3. a 8750H in your P50 wouldn't it be better fabricate a bracket for a P52 Mobo and use that? That's a lot less failure points and simpler too. I would say it's a better idea fab a mount for a new motherboard and find some smashed P52 or 53 a thrashed exterior. Or just buy a P52.

You may also tp smapi . Battery thresholds are configured by editing tlp's config file. In most recent versions it's /etc/tlp.conf . following are relevant settings START CHARGE THRESH BAT0 STOP CHARGE THRESH BAT0 There's also another setting that's used for Ultrabay or slice batteries START CHARGE THRESH BAT1 STOP CHARGE THRESH BAT1

On linux manage battery thresholds TLP t420 tested working both vendor bios and coreboot . Run sudo tlp-stat in Battery Features Charge Thresholds and Recalibrate section see have all necessary modules installed. To set temporary thresholds run tlp setcharge BAT0 start/stop percentage them persistent after reboots edit /etc/tlp.conf file.

In my opinion don't bash it around and don't spill anything on keyboard after many years find battery won't hold much of a charge anymore. But that applies all laptops. As extreme examples I have a 365XD that I bought in 2000 and won't power on any more. I have a 760EL that I bought in 2002 and works fine except battery. I also have an X61s about 10 years old T420 about 7 years old that work and currently have a 25th anniversary about 2 years old and these all work fine.

For reliability laptops are pretty reliable and usually last 8 years take care of them For replacement it entirely depends on what 're using laptop for. also depends on how fast future processors be. 're using it for office word processing then could be looking at a very long time. For example X230 and T430 were released in 2012 and still be used for basic office work and web browsing. Assuming have upgraded ram and moved a SSD drive T440P was released in late 2013 and probably still be effective for another 3-4 years at least. T540P was released at same time and probably be effective for 1-2 years longer than T440P. However from 2012-2017 Intel was focused making CPU's more energy efficient vs increasing speed. wasn't until T480 was released that CPU's had a big jump in processing power over previous year's laptops. Now AMD has come out faster CPU's and this encourage Intel come out faster CPU's. So in next few years competition may drive CPU's become noticeably faster than today's current CPU's. So replacability is not easily predictable because it really depends on whether / a faster CPU. Another example in 2008 Lenovo released X61. By 2016 X61 was dated and was not good enough play some Youtube videos and some 2K or 4K content. In contrast in 2012 X230 was released and it still play YouTube 2K and 4K content.

ThinkPads have pretty long lifespans. Currently I'm using a 10-year-old T410 and only thing that isn't doing good is battery. Then again T410s plural and not slim of course weren't ever rewarded for having especially good batteries.

USB-C power banks are for computers that be powered from a USB-C or Thunderbolt port. You have do your research before purchasing your computer. Acer A515-51G series requires a 45w-65w power supply. You always extend your battery power by changing your power settings Balanced or Battery Saver. For normal workloads expect about 5 hours of power while in Balance power mode. Any sort of gaming or processor intensive applications reduce that time significantly. Consider weight size of power bank. I look for something under 3 pounds that fit in laptop bag. Don't expect a power bank provide a laptop a full day of power. is useful for squeezing out an hour or two when really get work done. For traveling other devices it is a fair reserve power source. You have shop carefully because not all models have a 100w port. These links are not recommendations. They are intended give an idea of what is available and what features consider. You have look carefully at specs for portable power banks because they are mostly underpowered designed for smaller devices like phones tablets. P.S. Forget anything that has a solar panel or claims it power your devices from a solar panel. Most portable solar panels only have an output of 10w in EXTREME DIRECT SUNLIGHT. You then lose some of power in conversion which be a 40% loss in most cheaply made devices. Those devices won't charge an attached power bank in less than 40 hours of direct sunlight.

I'd boot into a Linux LiveUSB like Lubuntu and try running some nvme format and blkdiscard commands on it. drive is really dead it'd either not show up at all or those commands would fail in interesting ways. This is one-liner I use when I prep my NVMe drive for a fresh OS install boot into Ubuntu LiveUSB open Terminal and copy/paste sudo apt install 'nvme-cli' -y sync sudo blkdiscard --verbose '/dev/nvme0n1' sudo nvme format '/dev/nvme0n1' --reset --ses '1' --pil '0' --pi '0' --ms '0' sync

Undervolt numbers are different for different CPU GPU chips. Some does well beyond -80mV offset. But some crash. You have try little by little and apply some CPU GPU stress testing find out it's stable for longer periods. Use Intel Extreme Tuning Utility for CPU MSI Afterburner for GPU Voltage - Frequency curve adjustment is really good in that software . Remember Little steps. Like -5mV Stress Check temps for 30 mins it didn't crash -5mV more and so on. I was able get -80mV on an i5 and 900mV and 1900MHz on GPU. So my CPU was limited but GPU is efficient. But may not be case for every silicon. So don't try without testing for stability. OEMs set Voltage that is stable for All chips. Some may do good some may do bad. That's why for Low end laptops they won't Undervolt. Though Laptops like Alienware and Razor Undervolt pretty good out of box.

Okay listen i try something Though this thing require another monitor or tv supporting hdmi i am sure may have it I know this may sound somewhat awkward but this may lead us cause 1st step go Nvidia control panel And select manage 3d settings on left side Now on global settings select restore on bottom right this should reset anything default values now select preferred graphics processor as Nvidia and hit apply don't click on restore again now now go control panel and disable fast startup in power options now shutdown laptop better yet hard shutdown it by holding power button now keep your laptop plugged in dont run it on battery power 2nd step startup laptop immediately connect a 2nd display via hdmi only now click on notification icon on bottom right in Taskbar click on project icon and select second screen only don't see project button then click on expand Now this thing force laptop use discrete graphics card entirely for everything Now download and run intel processor diagnostic tool Now use laptop normally and check it freezes again and report back. also post a video of laptop connected external display showing line just like posted before This thing may take some time but it lead us component which is failing. Try this report back friend

Also now do one more little thing download and install intel xtu also keep your laptop connected second screen while doing this now open xtu then on left panel click on all controls and then click on graphics in left panel now set processor graphics voltage offset 0.050 yes read it right don't undervolt it but instead overvolt it now disconnect your laptop from 2nd display and keep using it as usual and definitely run a game or play video or do something for 1 hr at least and see it crashes and shows green lines again and report back me also ur pc restarts in middle then do check in xtu overvolt is applied or not u change processor graphics voltage offset then processor graphics media voltage change automatically too so don't worry about it and don't touch any other settings in xtu and report back how your laptop performs now friend .

He deleted recovery tools. disks have are full package of Acer recovery then could spend time doing process all over again. However this time around avoid interrupting process or overriding automated settings. You'll select delete everything option get original partitions recreated. This wipe entire drive and delete all partitions. Then recovery tools recreate proper partitions and restore original Windows 7 and Acer software. After mfg restore is finished I'd a disk image of entire drive for safekeeping. Then I'd run free Windows 10 upgrade update all Windows patches and then another disk image so won't have spend hours doing this all over again swap hard drives or have a serious software problem in future. Whatever do keep those Windows 7 recovery disks in a secure place since won't be able create them again.

Don't think about trying repaste your computer when lack expertise do it properly a high-quality thermal paste or carbon pad. risk is too high for potentially causing more damage during disassembly of computer. most common heat problem is from tinkering settings in an attempt overclock system without enough knowledge about computers in general. anyone has been adjusting performance settings reset everything defaults. second most common tends be related tinkering video card settings force NVIDIA card always act as primary. This has high-end GPU working harder all time instead of moments when it is really needed. Let Intel onboard GPU handle mundane tasks and keep power draw heat a minimum. third most common issue is CPU voltage running as computer is needed for high-end tasks. Modest undervolting has been extremely successful for a large number of reddit members. Other heat related issues have been simple things like not setting laptop on a firm surface i.e. not nestled snuggly in a blanket on your bed or sofa or other items blocking air vents.

Hey gotta chill yourself first. Everyone stumbles on obstacles and giving up is not answer. 1 Firstly most important of all and I cannot stress this enough did verify ISO according its checksum? Its GPG key? You search articles on how do this. 2 Have first updated BIOS latest version? Note when updating BIOS update it incrementally. Starting from version number directly after version in your BIOS then repeat until reach latest version. 3 Have tried other linux distros? Ubuntu Linux Mint Manjaro Solus are great distros for newcomers. Note your CPU and GPU is relatively new try distos that offer newer Linux kernels those that offer 5.x series kernels. You look at distro's changelog for more info. 4 Maybe flash drive or USB writing tool is problem. Note Grab another spare flash drive preferably 4GB or more and flash ISO using Rufus or Etcher. I like flash using Etcher as it validates files in flash drive after flashing. OR Try original drive in another computer this tell what problem is either computer or flash drive. 5 all else fails file a bug report distro dev tracker. They most likely help . Or post your problem in linux and elementary os subreddit or similar subreddits.

First that Sandisk is kinda junky for a supposed data center grade SSD. For those of us who manage data centers seeing that tag on a drive tells us it won't be great for performance but it'll probably be last drive in rack that might fail. I wouldn't expect much performance from a 6th gen i3 dual-core processor. Since didn't specify which model have in that series. might be lucky and have an M.2 NVMe port that significantly improve performance over any SATA SSD. A few models in that series also take a max of 32GB RAM so have an upgrade path that might be wasted on an i3 processor. I'm not advocating straining your budget I'm just making sure are aware of advantages and limits of that computer. You didn't mention cloned original drive or ran a clean install of Windows on that SSD. ran a clean install have some cleanup do. You'll disable some of Win10 resource chokes in background. i.e. Privacy settings Microsoft account sync settings Cortana settings Game Bar Game DVR settings etc. Keep in mind that your total RAM run at speed of slowest RAM have installed. While different sized RAM work in those slots may end up unexpected performance loss. DDR works best when it is balanced. same number of chips same speed and latency. This is real reason for recommendation of matched sets of RAM. You did something we are all guilty of occasionally doing had a spare stick of RAM stuck it in empty slot. performance dropped because RAM controller is working harder balance different amount of RAM in each slot in addition constantly adjusting for differences in speed and latency.

I'd try a Linux LiveUSB I believe that NVIDIA GPU should be supported well enough by open-source graphics driver may have manually re-clock high-performance 3D clock though . Try running this under a Terminal window DRI PRIME 1 glxinfo grep renderer should say something NVIDIA-related. From there run this wget -O '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64.zip' ' unzip '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64.zip' -d '/tmp' cd '/tmp/GpuTest Linux x64 ' DRI PRIME 1 ./GpuTest /test 'fur' /width '1280' /height '720' Which should run a stress test on NVIDIA GPU. it works then GPU is likely fine and it's just Windows being odd.

I. Set speed shift EPP 0 on main TP window II. Then go FIVR A SET TURBO RATIO LIMITS 1-6 34 each. B Then set offset voltage - 145.5 or - 140 that'd be safe I guess 150 works out for me C Then go CPU cache on same page and set same offset voltage Now on bottom right hand side select OK-SAVE VOLTAGES IMMEDIATELY III. Now go TPL A In turbo boost power limits boxes ENTER - 24 in 1st and 2nd box and 3rd should be 28 B Below this 'll find miscellaneous. In Max box enter 34 and press apply and ok. Save and minimize TP. Also don't forget add it in task scheduler autostart on logon. Now run any game and do let me know how this works out for . Play some CPU intensive game like GTA or Warzone.

How do I upgrade my HDD eithout losing warranty? Are in US? You 't legally lose your warranty by opening laptop unless actually cause provable damage by doing so. Simply opening laptop or any electronic including game consoles and breaking any void broken stickers or other indicators 't void warranty regardless of what manufacturer says. With that out of way though all Acer laptops I've had so far have a small doosection on bottom that allows add/replace HDDs easily without having open entire laptop. I don't imagine there's too many things that could go wrong putting HDD into laptop. You definitely find many videos of other people doing this other laptops for a general idea on process. For someone new this I imagine it would take about 5-15 minutes being careful. Anyone experienced could likely do it in less than 5 minutes. Typically a standard 2.5 HDD or SSD it involves 1. Removing a screw 2. Lifting panel off laptop 3. Removing HDD caddy it's in laptop still typically involves removing 4 screws 4. Put HDD into caddy typically via 4 separate screws 5. Carefully connect HDD while in caddy SATA/connection cable hardest part but easy 're careful and take your time 6. Reverse steps 1-3 put back 4 caddy screws put panel back put screw back 7. Power on laptop and do whatever HDD As why they didn't include HDD in laptop begin no idea. In my case I would have preferred HDD be outside laptop since I don't plan on using it at all and it would have saved me effort of taking it out lol

fans making a whirring sound could be result of dust in fan bearings. Predator Sense it is still installed show fan speeds. I own a 2016 Acer predator so i 't answer 1st question but since 2 and 3 are general i help avoid some of mistakes I made. 2. Check and monitor your temps. After about a year of usage suddenly my FPS for gaming tanked. I used Speccy and realised motherboard was overheating. I opened up laptop chassis and found that one of fan connectors for mobo was loose. Then same thing happened but for CPU and GPU. I changed horrible gunk Acer calls thermal paste and voila-temperatures in high 60's low 70's a gaming load. My only regret is I over-tightened screws and stripped some of them. Also clean exhaust fans from time time avoid build up of dust which increase your temperatures. Get a good waterproof backpack carry it extra padding. use it for work and home gaming invest in an extra power adapter don't it be original one . That way all have do is plug it in and won't risk damaging power adapter like I did. Plus its a real hassle cable manage and carry extra brick and cord. 3.I do recommend getting a good laptop cooler. I ordered this one but it hasn't been delivered yet. Again a mistake not use one from start as it actually boost performance since CPU and GPU boost frequencies be maintained thermal throttling doesn't occur. Let me know have any other doubts and congrats on your new laptop.

ruslan-fortnite is correct. You verify amount being reserved which sometimes be an indicator of a problem RAM by looking at Performance tab in Task Manager. I've worked Wake on LAN/Magic Packet utilities for years and have never heard of having enable power PCIe . Considering that PCIe is tied system bus I think it would be harder find a way disable it. What should be looking for is setting permit PCIe devices wake computer.Boot BIOS navigate Power Management Setup DISABLE Deep Power Off Mode ENABLE Power On by PCIE Devices Press F10 save changes. For anyone else reading this your BIOS probably has one simple entry Enable Wake on LAN . Now boot into Windows and check your Wireless and LAN adapter properties in Device Manager. View Power Management tab check box allow this device wake computer .You might experiment Magic Packet option.

There are probably two ways this happened - maybe service just made a mistake by replacing faulty SSD wrong type. should not happen but they are also just people so sometimes this is case. contact them without any delay after repair they should correct this mistake your device is out of warranty. There might also be another explanation - in lot of laptop they use same type of SSDs but from different manufacturers and a slightly different specifications. Perhaps originally there was faster SSD in your laptop but service had only same type but slower ones on stock so they used them. Then it might be ok. There is also a third possibility there is problem this new SSD. But only service get an answer and eventually a solution. Regarding warranty - in my country warranty is extended for time laptop is in service center maybe it is same at your country. But in this case contact service without any delay after repair I do not think it is relevant.
